DEBATE.TITLE: DEPUTY PRESIDENT AND CHAIRMAN OF COMMITTEES

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received a letter from Senator Crichton-Browne resigning his office of Deputy President and Chairman of Committees. I table the document.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I remind the Senate that it should now choose one of its members to be Deputy President and Chairman of Committees.
—Mr President, I propose to the Senate for its Deputy President and Chairman of Committees Senator Margaret Reid, and I move:

PARA.TAB: That Senator Reid be appointed Deputy President and Chairman of Committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further nominations?There being no further nominations, I declare Senator Reid is elected Deputy President and Chairman of Committees in accordance with the standing orders, and I congratulate her.

—Mr President, if I may, I would like to thank the Senate for the honour of bestowing this position upon me. It is an office that I have sought and one which I am very pleased to fulfil. I look forward to fulfilling the role, and I undertake to do it to the very best of my ability, with fairness and, hopefully, with good humour.

PARA.TAB: The election has not come about in the normal course. As Senator Crichton-Browne leaves the position that he has held, I am sure all senators will acknowledge the contribution that he has made, and particularly the role that he played in restructuring the Senate committee system. While I am on my feet, I would like to be the first to congratulate Senator Jacinta Collins on her election to this place.

In taking on the position of Chairman of Committees and Deputy President of the Senate, I think all senators here would know that I leave the position of opposition whip with some reluctance. It is a job that I have enjoyed enormously over the years. I want to acknowledge those I have worked with in the position. I think we have been a fairly happy subset of the Senate and have enjoyed working together. I think of Senator Knowles and Senator Panizza, who have been deputy whips to me since I took on the position in 1987, and Senator Bourne of the Democrats. One could not really call Senator Harradine, Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts whips, but they were always there and one could not ignore their presence; at various times they became part of the group.

I particularly thank Senator Tambling, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, Senator Brownhill and Senator O'Chee, who have been National Party whips during this time. I thank most particularly Senator Jones. He and I have had a very good and happy working relationship. I think we came to understand each other and knew when which words meant what, and when silence meant something else. Gerry, I have enjoyed working with you. I shall miss the contact we have had and I have had with those who have been supporting you over the years that you have been whip. I can see Senator Faulkner over there; he has risen to great heights. There is also Senator McKiernan, who fulfilled the position for three years, I think, and more recently Senator Foreman.

The whip's office is not one that people take much notice of, and it certainly has no profile outside the building. But for those who have been privileged to be a part of that small group, it has been a very happy relationship; so has working with the various parliamentary liaison officers, who are also an important part of the whips group. I thank the Senate for this honour, and I look forward to fulfilling the position.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I know I speak for all government senators when I very warmly congratulate Senator Reid on her appointment as Deputy President and chair, or chairperson, of committees. History having now been made—Senator Reid's appointment to this position makes it the first time that a woman has held it—perhaps the time has come to formally adopt the name `Chair of Committees' rather than `Chairman of Committees' in recognition of that appointment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Reid is in the unique position of having been chosen by the Commonwealth parliament itself in 1981, after Senator Knight's death, and she has been re-elected to the Senate on five occasions so far—a feat which not many senators are likely to emulate, let alone surpass; not that I think Senator McMullan, from the ACT as well, will be letting any grass grow under him in that respect.

Senator Reid was elected, as she has acknowledged, deputy government whip in 1982-83 and has been opposition whip from 1983, in one capacity or another. It is a very long period of service to a party, and to the Senate more generally. We fully anticipate that Senator Reid will carry out her new functions with the same commitment and sense of responsibility that she has always displayed in her whip's duties. I can very accurately say that Senator Reid is popular on all sides of this chamber for her personal qualities of warmth, charm and humanity, and we fully expect those qualities to be even more consistently and publicly on display in her new role. We wish her all the best and we expect nothing less than that from her in that new job.

I also take this opportunity to express appreciation for the services of the former Deputy President, Senator Noel Crichton-Browne. I said at the time of Senator Crichton-Browne's appointment in August 1993 that I had always considered him to be above the political fray in this place—whatever might be the case elsewhere—and I looked forward to him exercising his responsibilities as Deputy President with not only, as I said, efficiency and dispatch, but also wisdom, judgment and even-handed good humour. I can say again quite honestly that, during his tenure in the office, Senator Crichton-Browne displayed amply all those characteristics. I think we all regret the circumstances that have led to him leaving the position and we wish him well for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, I also warmly congratulate Senator Reid on her election today. I thank non-opposition senators for the fact that they have been prepared to endorse her without a contest.

PARA.TAB: Senator Reid brings many qualities to this position—not only, of course, that she was a South Australian, brought up in South Australia and educated there; not only because she is a legal practitioner, and we all recognise the benefit of that in effective legislative practice; not only because she has given a lifetime commitment to politics and to her political party—I think she was a Young Liberal president some little time ago—not only because she is a competent legislator; and not only because she has a particular interest in helping build the parliaments of the South Pacific, an interest which she will be able to pursue in her new role.

We support her today, firstly, because of her commitment to this institution, which we regard as vitally important. She has demonstrated, through her work on the Procedures Committee, the Department of the Senate committee, the Selection of Bills Committee and all such bodies, a commitment to this institution. We support her because of her commitment to the effective and efficient working of the Senate, and we have seen that in her many years as whip and as deputy whip. We also support her for her sometimes forgotten commitment to the people other than the politicians who work in this place. They will be very pleased to learn of her election today.

She is also, of course—and I need not remind honourable senators of this—a woman. She has not been put up by us because of the fact that she is a woman; nevertheless we are proud that we have made a little bit of history today in putting her forward to the Senate for election and she being elected the first woman Deputy President of this place. We know that she will be objective and fair in her work. We also know that she will be firm but, as I said, she will exercise that firmness in a fair way. We congratulate Senator Reid and wish her well in her post.

I also want to make mention of Senator Crichton-Browne's contribution. We regret the circumstances that have led us to this election here today. We recognise that Noel has made a decision in the interests of his party and we appreciate that fact. We understand that it has nothing to do with the way in which he conducted himself in the office of Deputy President, which was in a way of which I think all senators can be proud.

Senator Reid mentioned his contribution to helping to strengthen and further develop the committee system in this place and that will be part of his legacy, as will the way he conducted himself in the chair. He was always well-briefed, fair and prepared to take on the difficult issues in this place. I think he can retire from the position, not having held it for long, but nevertheless in a position to be proud of the contribution that he has made. I wish to have recorded my appreciation of that contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Democrats I, too, congratulate Senator Reid. We have great confidence that she will bring to the office of Deputy President the sorts of qualities that most of us know from her in this chamber as whip but also from her membership of various committees. I have had the pleasure of serving with her on various committees. I think we know that she is always open to argument and discussion and that she is a direct communicator. As others have said, she is a warm and cheerful person and I think that those qualities, along with fairness, are qualities that she will probably need to draw upon quite often in future months.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate the Liberal Party, too, for proposing for the position of Deputy President of the Senate a woman who has been elected as the first woman to hold that position. Perhaps in a different situation the Democrats might have seen themselves in that position as well. We wish you well, Margaret. Might I take this opportunity to say we look forward to a continuation of a productive relationship with the new opposition whip, Senator Panizza, whose relationship and sparring with us goes back many years.

It is history that the Democrats voted against Senator Crichton-Browne the first time he was the Liberal nominee; and the reasons for that were clearly articulated at the time. I want to close this phase by saying that, since his election as Deputy President, Senator Crichton-Browne has fulfilled that role in a very capable way with a wonderful balance of judicious use of humour and very fair application of the standing orders. The point we made at the time of our opposition has now been addressed and I want to put on the record that we were very happy with the fair and competent way in which he exercised his role as Deputy President.
I also take this opportunity to congratulate Senator Jacinta Collins. We now have two Evanses and two Collinses.
Opposition senators—And two Macdonalds.

TALK.START.PARA: —And two Macdonalds; but I think we have sorted out the one over there. We wish Senator Jacinta Collins a happy and productive time with us in the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Party members of the Senate congratulate Senator Reid on her elevation to the position of Deputy President. The National Party took no part in the ballot, but we had a meeting while the Liberals were having their meeting and we endorsed unanimously Senator Reid's taking this position. I assure her that she has our full support and our best wishes. Senator Reid was the coalition whip when I came to this place in 1983. I warn the Senate that she is no pushover. She can be very firm and we cannot take her for granted in any way. But she is a warm and friendly person and I am sure she will do her job in a very fair manner.

PARA.TAB: I certainly recognise the contribution that Senator Crichton-Browne made to the Senate in his former position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also congratulate Senator Reid on her accession to the position of chair of committees. There were two things she said that need a little clarification. The first, as I got it down, was that she said the whips office is one that people do not take a great deal of notice of. I point out that that does not include those who count; they certainly take a lot of notice of it. I have noticed that when Senator Reid cracks the whip people certainly take a great deal of notice of what she says.

PARA.TAB: The second thing she said which may need clarification concerned Senator Chamarette, Senator Margetts and me. She said that perhaps the word `whip' would not apply to us. We have been involved in discussions in order to see that this place is run in an orderly way. Those discussions have been with Senator Reid and Senator Gerry Jones. Senator Reid, you might think that being whip of a party is an onerous task; but to be the whip of an individual who has to explain to all and sundry why he voted in a particular way on a particular bill does require some degree of discipline. It may not be terribly obvious to all concerned in this place, but I would like to be regarded as one of the whips. However, I do not expect the Remuneration Tribunal to pay me higher duties for that.

It is very important to have Senator Reid, a person with experience, a pleasant character, legal training and tenacity, as chair of committees. The Committee of the Whole functions are supposed to be performed by the Friday legislative committees of the Senate. It may not be known to everybody, but some of us know that funding for these committees—and perhaps for the whole committee system—is under attack. This is not the time to debate that point but Senator Reid, with her strength of character and ability to put forward a very good argument, may be very handy. I am sure that she will be a great asset to you, Mr President, in your very fine work in that area.

I look forward to working with Senator Panizza, who I understand is taking over as the whip. I also look forward to working with Senator Calvert, from the state of Tasmania, who I have been told is to be deputy whip.

I congratulate Senator Jacinta Collins on her accession. `Accession' is not the right word. I congratulate her on her appointment to this place. Accession presupposes some going up of the ladder. I do not know whether that is the case for all of us. I look forward to her contribution to this Senate and to its committees.

I have found Senator Noel Crichton-Browne to be absolutely fair in his work as Chairman of Committees. Like others, I regret the circumstances that have led to his decision, but I wish him all the best. I do not think he needs that, because he is a person of a good deal of strength. Nevertheless, I place on record my appreciation of his services in that particular office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts and I also wish to congratulate our new Deputy President and chair of committees. Her abilities and good qualifications for this position are well known to those of us who have worked with her in her capacity as opposition whip and in any other capacities. I commend her predecessor, Senator Crichton-Browne, for standing aside from this position. I also wish to acknowledge that we have always found him fair and just in his conduct and in his carrying out of this role. We express our appreciation for that.

PARA.TAB: We welcome with great pleasure Senator Jacinta Collins as a colleague in this place. We do so with mixed feelings, because I think there is great sadness that she is replacing our respected colleague Senator Olive Zakharov. But we are thrilled that she has been replaced by a woman and by someone who, I am sure, will contribute a great deal to this place. Finally, while there is no doubt that our Deputy President has gained her position because of her abilities and not for her gender, it is with great pleasure that we acknowledge she has made history by becoming the first woman to take the role of Deputy President of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not too sure whether, as government whip, I should stand to congratulate Senator Reid! But it is with warm congratulations that we wish you the very best in your position as Chairman of Committees. Maybe at some time we will wish you were back in the whips office! I do not mean that as any reflection on Senator Panizza, because I think we will work very well together. Margaret, I warmly congratulate you. If you carry out the duties as Deputy President and Chairman of Committees in the same way as you did as opposition whip, I believe this place will be much better for the service that you will give it. I congratulate you very warmly on behalf of all my colleagues.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the way Senator Noel Crichton-Browne carried out his duties as Deputy President, I think everyone in this chamber would recognise that he carried them out very warmly and very well. He was very clear in the way that he handled the position. He did not play favourites on either side of the house. Noel, my congratulations for the job that you carried out.
Lastly, I would like to congratulate Senator Jacinta Collins on her appointment to this place. I am sure that nothing would be better for this place than to have two Senator Collinses here.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like briefly to add my congratulations to Senator Reid, whom I know I will work with very well. I have experienced her company on both committees and travelling and know how good a companion she is, how competent she is and how well-loved she is in the Pacific, to which somebody has already referred.

PARA.TAB: I too would like to add my thanks to Senator Crichton-Browne. Like everybody else, I am sorry to see the way that this occurred, but I thank him for the support that he has given me in my role. He has carried out his task with strength, dignity and great competence and I wish him well. Finally, I welcome Senator Jacinta Collins to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank senators for their congratulations and good wishes. Mr President, I look forward to working with you as well. I am sure we will get on well together. I particularly want to thank senators for their warm good wishes this afternoon.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Defence—
—Ray is on holidays, is he?

—Senator Ray is not on holidays, as Senator Alston vulgarly interjects, but will be absent from question time this week as he is still overseas on official business. Senator Ray is currently in Europe, of course, representing the Governor-General at the VE celebrations. In Senator Ray's absence, I will be taking questions on matters relating to the defence portfolio and Senator McMullan will represent the ministers for industrial relations and tourism.
—by leave—I have been somewhat pre-empted; nevertheless, I would like to announce that we have elected Senator John Panizza as our whip and Senator Paul Calvert as our deputy whip.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind the minister that this government solemnly promised the Australian people at the last election that it would not put up taxes; it would not introduce new taxes; it would abolish tax for all pensioners; and it would allow personal use of accumulated superannuation for home loans. It even legislated tax cuts to reinforce its promise. All of these promises it has broken and, worse, it seems never intended to keep. What credibility does this government claim when it puts down a budget tonight to the background of such blatant electoral abuse? Why should the people believe the word of Mr Keating, who has demonstrated on so many occasions that he will do or say anything to get elected but will then treat the voters with such scant regard? Why shouldn't the parliament hold this dishonest government responsible for its commitments?

—The government's credibility will be self-evidently whole and intact after the budget speech tonight. But beyond that I do not propose to respond to any question that invites speculation about this or that budget measure.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I note the recent debate over the potential movement of untreated imported grain into rural areas. Would the minister advise the Senate of the current status of this important issue and how the government proposes to deal with concerns that have been expressed, particularly by the grain industry representatives?

—A casual observer who had been listening, watching and reading much of the debate on this matter since we sat last could be forgiven for thinking that the federal government has sanctioned the immediate importation of a million tonnes of diseased foreign grain for up country. In fact, you have only to go to today's press—a story in the Courier-Mail—to see that asserted once again. A tremendous amount of misinformation has been put out about this. In fact, nothing could be further from the truth, as those that are closest to the debate know.

PARA.TAB: The federal government has absolutely no intention of allowing the movement of unprocessed imported grain into rural areas unless it can be demonstrated that this can be done in accordance with strict quarantine protocols laid down by AQIS.

The government has approved a series of trials to demonstrate whether untreated grain can be moved up country in a secure manner. The way in which those trials are to be conducted has not yet been determined, and the trials themselves are not even proposed to begin until next month.

The Bureau of Resource Sciences has identified seven states in the United States as being low risk for the three diseases of quarantine concern to Australia. The diseases are loose kernel smut, head smut and sorghum downy mildew. On information currently available, there appears to be four states in which these diseases have not been detected for at least five years, and three other states where one or more of these diseases has or have been detected at only very low incidences.

For example, I advised the Senate in March, on the basis of information available to me then, that those diseases had not been detected in Kansas and Nebraska for five years. Information available since then indicates that, while this is still so for loose kernel smut, there have been low incidences of sorghum downy mildew in Kansas and of head smut in both Nebraska and Kansas. I am advised that the states which appear at this stage to have had no record of these diseases for at least five years are Illinois, Colorado, Okalahoma and Missouri. But in order to establish this beyond question, we are sending a technically qualified delegation to the seven low-risk states of the United States in just a few days to determine—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going with them to help them with your expertise?

—No; you would complain if I was not in the Senate, or Senator Robert Hill would. We are sending a delegation in a few days to determine at first hand the precise situation in regard to matters of quarantine concern, including—importantly—the actual handling of the grain through the transport chain in the United States. The delegation will consist of one senior officer from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and one from the Bureau of Resource Sciences.

PARA.TAB: I was pleased to see in a press statement issued just yesterday that the Grains Council of Australia has accepted my invitation to join the study and intends to send its Senior Vice-President, Mr Allan McCallum, and Senior Research Officer, Mr James Price. I discussed that with the President only this morning. In order to extend the technical expertise of the delegation, an invitation has also been extended to the Chief Plant Pathologist of the Queensland Department of Primary Industries, and I am confident this will be accepted.

The study trip and the formulation of guidelines for the trials have been put together as part of the government's ongoing investigation of every aspect of this issue, given its importance to the security of the grains industry. Since this issue was first raised, the government has been at pains to point out that no decisions would be made on the movement of untreated grain up country without the most stringent investigation.

To clear the record, AQIS currently has applications from six feedlot establishments for the movement up country of 70,000 tonnes of barley and sorghum from low-risk US states that are pending the outcome of these trials. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister would also be aware of reports that the government is proposing trials to be conducted using 500 tonnes of grain. Is this correct?

—No, it is not. It follows on from the trials I have just discussed. That has never been correct. As I have stated, the conditions of the trials have not been finalised but that does not stop people, such as those in the New South Wales Farmers Federation, from putting that out in press statements.

PARA.TAB: The figure of 500 tonnes was an estimate that came from the Australian Lot Feeders Association of the amount of grain that would be carried at normal operational rates during two eight-hour shifts. It was envisaged by AQIS that separate trials would be required for each feedlot for each kind of imported grain. That was stated from the start. At the very least, that would require trials of 3,000 tonnes. So the figure of 500 tonnes is and always has been a furphy.

I stress again that the details of the trials themselves have not been determined. The trials are not even due to start until next month. We have been continually negotiating this difficult issue with all parties since well before Christmas. I am having another meeting tomorrow with the Grains Council and the National Farmers Federation and, as I have said before, I am absolutely confident that the issue will be resolved to the ultimate satisfaction of all parties.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Only a few months ago, former Treasurer John Dawkins admitted to deceiving the Australian people by deliberately understating estimates of revenue from indirect taxes in the 1993 budget. Last night we had former Labor staffer and Treasury secretary Tony Cole confirming that the One Nation forecasts were deliberately fiddled in the Prime Minister's office, obviously on directions from the Prime Minister himself. In these circumstances, on the very day when the l-a-w tax cuts are set to become the l-i-e tax cuts, why should Australians believe anything the government says or promises in tonight's pre-election budget?

—Mr President, it seems that hell hath no fury like a former departmental secretary scorned. Be that as it may, I am advised that the forecasts for the One Nation statement in early 1992 were fixed in exactly the same way that all economic forecasts are that feed into the budgetary processes or statements of this kind. Those forecasts are fixed—and I use the word in its ordinary, proper meaning—as a result of the deliberations of the JEFG, as it is called, the Joint Economic Forecasting Group, which is a group of senior Treasury officials and other key departmental officials sitting with the Prime Minister's and the Treasurer's economic advisers of the day. That is the way in which those forecasts have always been struck. That is the way in which they were struck on this particular occasion.

PARA.TAB: The forecast for the period 1992-93 was agreed to be appropriately set at something over four per cent, without apparently much disagreement at all as between the advisers. In the event, of course, for 1992-93, that forecast was not met because the growth outturn was only of the order of 2.5 per cent. But there were plenty of other people who got that particular year's forecast wrong around the world, including the OECD, the IMF and a number of other international forecasters who had to progressively revise down their forecast for growth. That was the case for us as well.

What is important to appreciate is that the outyear forecasts as published in that 1992 One Nation statement—and they are all there in the document and I will remind you of them in a moment; over which forecasts there was apparently some lively discussion bordering on, one might almost say, disagreement within the JEFG—were either broadly achieved or, in fact, exceeded.

For 1993-94, the One Nation forecast was 4.5 per cent; in fact, the achieved rate was 4.2 per cent. For 1994-95, the current year, the forecast rate was 4.25 per cent in One Nation. The outturn for this year, when announced, will be, we expect, in the range of 4 1/2 to five per cent. For next year, 1995-96, the One Nation forecast set by this particular group about whom Mr Cole is talking was 3.75 per cent, and our present forecast for 1995-96 is exactly the same figure—3.75 per cent. So anyone who suggests that those One Nation figures were in any way pumped or inflated or the product of any kind of deliberate fabrication is simply getting their facts wrong. It does not represent the circumstance; it does not represent the process that was at work.

I think there is one final general point that also needs to be acknowledged; that is, figures of this kind are not the property of any particular officials within any particular department; they are the government's figures. The government has ownership of them. The government assumes responsibility for them. When the government gets those figures wrong, we expect to get the blame. When the government gets the figures right, we expect to—even though we never do—get the applause as a government because we accept the responsibility, we make the judgment.

It is interesting to see how few of you have been interested in chasing down the personal officials who may have been responsible for last year's budget figures, for example, when we underestimated in our forecast growth; we underestimated employment growth; we underestimated investment growth; and we overestimated inflation. Where did we hear from you then in terms of the accuracy of that particular process and who was to be responsible for it? The point is that forecasting is an inexact science which represents a balance of inputs from a variety of sources. It is done in the best possible way that we or any other government can do, and that is what was done on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we presume from that that all that Tony Cole said last night was a product of his fevered imagination? Are you going to get the members of JEFG to put their versions on affidavit to say that Tony Cole is lying? The fact is, isn't it, that there have been at least four instances that we know about where Paul Keating has manipulated economic forecasts—12 per cent investment forecast in the 1988 budget, current account deficit estimate in the 1989 budget, growth and unemployment estimates in the 1990 budget and, of course, the One Nation forecast? With these prior convictions for dishonesty, why should the Australian public not regard the Prime Minister as someone who will simply say or do anything to stay in office?

—Let the figures again speak for themselves: 1993-94, One Nation forecast 4.5 per cent, outturn result 4.2 per cent; 1994-95, One Nation forecast 4.25 per cent, outturn result likely to be of the order of 4.75 per cent—much better; 1995-96, One Nation forecast 3.75 per cent, likely forecast outturn at the moment 3.75 per cent—exactly the same. Let the figures speak for themselves.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of the President of the Tasmanian Legislative Council, John Stopp. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome him to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to his recent visit to China where he reached agreement with the Chinese authorities on the speedy return to China of the boat people who arrived in Australia late last year. Can the minister outline to the Senate what developments have taken place since the minister's visit and can he confirm that the first group of boat people will be returned to China this month as expected?

—I thank Senator Colston for his question because the return of the boat people to southern China is indeed critical to the government's continuing efforts to protect the integrity of its humanitarian program. If we are to continue to offer people in fear of persecution in their homelands a chance to build new lives in Australia as refugees, it is important that we ensure that our policies and programs are not compromised by illegal boat arrivals to this country.

PARA.TAB: My visit to China last month was extremely successful in this respect. Whilst discussions had been continuing in a very constructive way since the end of last year, direct contact with Chinese officials at national and local levels was invaluable in terms of finalising the arrangements which had to be made for the Chinese authorities to continue to offer protection to these refugees.

As Senator Colston noted, it was agreed that the first group would be returned to China during May. I am pleased to inform the Senate that a group of 53 people left Port Hedland this morning. That group is scheduled to arrive in Nanning in southern China in a couple of hours time. Today's departure was incident free. It is the first of what is planned to be a regular movement back to China of those who arrived in Australia over the last six months or so.

I must say, Mr President, that the approach taken by the Australian government was based on a recognised need for cooperation with the Chinese authorities. We have moved with quiet determination to develop a practical, workable and sustainable response, which at times required patience and resolve, and today's departure represents the first dividend of our approach.

Senators will recall that on 30 September last year I announced a number of measures in response to this issue, including senior level discussions. Those discussions produced a memorandum of understanding on 25 January this year. The MOU covered the return of these people to China and their continued protection. On 9 February this year the parliament passed legislation which declared China a safe third country for Vietnamese refugees previously resettled in China. Both the MOU and the subsequent legislation were supported publicly by the UNHCR, which organisation has been closely involved with the Vietnamese since they were resettled in southern China in the early 1980s.

I acknowledge that we still have a way to go before all the illegal arrivals covered by the MOU and the legislation are returned to China. There will almost certainly be other illegal arrivals, but the important thing is that we have now put in place the framework for a workable response. The return of the group today gives some practical substance to that response.

In that respect I must thank the Chinese authorities, which have been most cooperative from the beginning. I also thank the Chinese ambassador to Australia. In less than five months we have negotiated an agreement with China, we have passed the required legislation and we have seen the first lot of boat people returned. That is a remarkable achievement: even more so when it is compared with the time that it took for similar arrangements to be put in place by Hong Kong and Japan, which countries took some 18 months or so to achieve similar results.

I must thank Senator McKiernan and Jackie Watkins for their assistance in China; the departmental officers for their work here and in China, particularly secretary Chris Conybeare and assistant secretaries Dennis Richardson and Mark Sullivan; and our ambassador in Beijing. The message we want to give to the world is that we are open for legal migration. We will remain open to assist record levels of refugees when they come here, but we are not open to illegal migration.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I note President Chirac's strong commitment to further developing the French nuclear arsenal in clear breach of France's obligation under the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, whereby it is supposed to wind back its nuclear forces. Can it be said that the minister has supported France's nuclear interests and those of the other nuclear powers in arguing for their nuclear privileges to be extended indefinitely at the current NPT review conference? Is not the fact that President Chirac is considering the resumption of nuclear testing just kicking sand in the face of Australia's support? Did the minister underestimate French resolve? Will he withdraw his support for France's position before the NPT review conference concludes later this week, or at the very least insist on stronger commitments from France and the others to fulfil their disarmament obligations?

—It is the case that France, Britain and China, three nuclear powers, have not gone as rapidly down the path of actual disarmament and destruction of nuclear weapons as has been the case with the United States and Russia, which have embarked, under the START I and START II treaties, on a very substantial process of eliminating nuclear stockpiles. The starting points for the stockpiles of the three smaller nuclear powers is very much smaller than those of the other two. That is one of the reasons why they have been dragging their feet somewhat. Nonetheless, they are under real pressure from all of us at the nuclear non-proliferation conference to make serious commitments in that respect. I hope and believe that they will be honoured. Indeed, it is to be expected that there will emerge from the NPT conference in New York a pretty clear declaration of obligations in this respect so far as all the nuclear weapons states are concerned.

PARA.TAB: So far as nuclear testing is concerned, we have made our position absolutely clear on the record. In my case, I did so yesterday in a statement, following discussions I had with foreign minister Juppe a couple of weeks ago in France. On all predictions, he is likely to be the prime minister of France in the new government and will have a continuing influence in this respect. We have made very clear over and again our opposition to any resumption of testing by France in the South Pacific or anywhere else. We hope very much that that testing will be avoided.

The Chirac administration and its key spokesmen, including the new president himself, will remain studiously non-committal on the subject of the resumption of tests, making the point that they want to keep their force modernised and serviceable. They need some kind of testing, whether by way of actual explosions or simulation, to enable that to occur. They say that they are not wedded to testing by way of underground explosions but will take advice on whether the same results are achievable through simulation.

We can only hope that at least that result will be the case. There is some chance that it may, because the French are very conscious of the number of countries not only in this region but around the world that are urging them to play a responsible leadership role in this respect. They do not want France to just go down the path of looking inwardly and self-consciously at its own interests but rather at the larger interests of a world that wants to see genuine nuclear disarmament.

Any kind of testing designed to keep a stockpile intact or modernised would be anathema to Senator Kernot, as she has indicated in her question. I can perfectly well understand that result. However, I hope she agrees with me that at least the avoidance of outright testing in Mururoa Atoll through explosions is a significant start. We hope that from at least that beginning it will follow.

Beyond that, I say again for the record that Australia has enjoyed very warm and productive relations with France in recent years. We certainly look forward to maintaining that relationship with the Chirac presidency. We have every confidence that France, under its new administration, will play a positive and responsible role not only on the non-proliferation issue and, hopefully, in the context of the ongoing discussions about a comprehensive test ban treaty, in which its role is extremely important, but also in a whole variety of other policy issues in which we have a major interest, not least in the South Pacific.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does `serious commitment' mean? How do you reconcile this pursuit of modernisation, whether it is by computer simulation or it is by testing in the Pacific? You did not answer the last part of my question: are you prepared to press more closely and are you prepared to indicate how you are going to achieve this insistence on stronger commitments from France and the others?

—Those commitments are being very actively pursued in New York at the moment as part of the nuclear non-proliferation conference, which is expected to come to conclusion over the next week or so. That is the matter in issue: certain scepticism on the part of a great many countries around the world about the real commitment of the nuclear weapons powers to the ultimate objective of complete elimination of nuclear weapons and a desire to commit them to that particular objective and to steps by which it might credibly and reasonably be reached.

PARA.TAB: Australia shares that view. We make no bones about our commitment to the ultimate elimination completely of nuclear weapons, even if we do acknowledge that that is going to take some considerable time to achieve and involve a step-by-step process during the course of which you have to realistically expect that the nuclear weapons powers will want to maintain their armouries intact. But they are not inconsistent objectives and we are working with many other like-minded countries in order to achieve just the result that you are describing.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. The government originally predicted benefits to Australia from our signing the Uruguay Round of GATT of $5.5 billion after five years, despite being unwilling to conduct a complete sector-by-sector analysis to check those broad predictions. Whilst it is true that our exports are growing, did these predictions also make allowance for the huge and inevitable increase in imports that are now so evident? Given recent World Bank reports that even the predictions of benefits to the agricultural sector may be illusory and that the World Bank has noted that, for the EU, Japan and the US, agricultural protection may not drop as a result of the choice of base year and `dirty tariffication', how can the government justify the level of sacrifices exacted from many value added industries, including those processing primary commodities for the local market?

—The fatal flaw in the first part of Senator Margetts's article is that there have been no reductions in tariffs driven by the Uruguay Round for Australia. We made our decisions about our domestic arrangements concerning protection in advance of the conclusion of the Uruguay Round for domestic reasons—domestic reasons which I agree with and Senator Margetts does not. That is a perfectly proper matter of difference on public policy.

PARA.TAB: To pretend that those things which preceded it were caused by it does not add to the analysis of the outcome of the Uruguay Round. There is a well-known logical fallacy: sometimes you can say that because one thing follows another it is caused by it. In this instance we got a unique version of it: because something preceded something it might somehow or other have been caused by it. I do not understand that point.

You then come to a more important issue, which is the publicity concerning the World Bank report claiming that the benefits to Australian agriculture from the Uruguay Round would be less than the ABARE analysis in Australia. In many ways we welcome that World Bank report. The message it sends to the major agricultural-distorting economies—the United States, the European Union and Japan—is that the process of agricultural reform globally is far from over. What took place as a result of the Uruguay Round was merely a welcome first step, but there is still a long way to go.

The distinction between the analysis the Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has made and that made by the World Bank is that ABARE took into account additional important benefits to Australia such as market access, which was not part of the analysis made by the World Bank. It took into account the fact that, as from this year, we will be able to export rice to Japan and Korea. It took into account the fact that we will be able to export hundreds of millions of dollars worth of beef to the United States over and above that which we could previously do.

So those are things which the World Bank assessment, because it was a global assessment, was unable to take into account, but they are of enormous benefit to Australians. I would suggest that if you do not agree with that you should go into the rural areas of Western Australia and seek to persuade them that some of those benefits are not in their interests. I would be very interested in the outcome. That is an important plus for Australia out of the World Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who do you want to do that?
—Senator Margetts.
—How often are you anywhere other than in Canberra?

—Grow up. She thinks that it is a very bad idea that we should do these important things. I would like to see her persuade those people who agree with Senator Crane that it was in fact a very important and positive outcome for Australian agriculture, even though a lot more remains to be done.

PARA.TAB: The other thing in the World Bank report which I have not heard Senator Margetts refer to is that the allegations that the least developed countries would suffer from the Uruguay Round were wrong and that in fact they would disproportionately benefit from the Uruguay Round benefits. As a percentage of their GDP they would get bigger benefits than the developed countries. People have always asserted the contrary, and it was a pleasure to see the World Bank challenge those assump tions.

Overall, we welcome that report. It says to the majors there is more to be done, but it does not in any way undermine the fact that the benefits to agriculture for Australia from the Uruguay Round are substantial and continuing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister, but I am wondering whose feet are in the clouds. We have gone from a positive balance of trade to a negative of nearly $1 billion a month just in one year. If our government continues to pretend that our naivety in trade policy and negotiations is not creating huge problems in our balance of payments, how can you ever expect the people of Australia to believe that either a tighter fiscal policy or a further hike in interest rates will fix the problem of our balance of payments?

—I do not quite know how to answer this question. When we point out the fact that the conclusion Senator Margetts asserts does not follow from the assumption she makes but that the supplementary question is based on exactly the same assumption, it is very hard to give an effective response. I can only reiterate that while it is a cause of serious concern in Australia that we have a balance of payments deficit, whatever we had done under the Uruguay Round, if we were investing more than we were saving we would have a current account deficit. It is a matter of arithmetic.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, Senator Crowley. Just over a year ago the Prime Minister insisted that there was:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . nothing around that warrants a change—
in the Medicare levy. In fact, he boasted that:
Medicare is working so well that people are leaving the private health system and joining the public health system.
Since then Dr Lawrence has gone on record as saying that she had:
. . . given a very strong commitment and so has the Prime Minister, that there'll be no increase in the Medicare levy.
Does your government stand by this commitment or have you again misled the Australian public over increases to Medicare?

TALK.START.PARA: —Those quotes that you give, Senator, refer to information of a year ago and were issued in response to recommendations to increase the levy by the ACTU caucus working group that reported on Graham Richardson's private health insurance proposals. The statement was true; there was no intention to raise the levy as part of the private health insurance reforms. Whether or not there is a proposal to increase the levy now you will find out tonight.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the recent statements on Iran. I ask the minister: what did the government mean when the minister's spokesperson was quoted as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . there is no evidence on the public record to establish that Iran is guilty of sponsoring terrorism.
Is there not other evidence available to the government to support this assessment? If so, will the Australian government support the United States in its imposition of a trade embargo on Iran?

TALK.START.PARA: —I should, frankly, acknowledge that in this context it is not really helpful to distinguish between evidence on and off the public record. What matters is what Iran's behaviour actually is and what the Australian government can do, if anything, to influence it. There certainly has been longstanding high-level Iranian government support for organisations like Hezbollah and Hamas, intense opposition expressed to Israel and the Middle East peace process and little respect shown for the human rights of political and religious dissidents. The Australian government has found these positions deeply unpalatable and has consistently said so. We also remain concerned about Iran's intentions in relation to the acquisition of nuclear and chemical weapons capability. But our generally cordial relationship with Iran and the strong trade and commercial links between our two countries have put us in a strong position to maintain a much more direct and critical dialogue with the Iranians on these issues than would otherwise have been possible.

PARA.TAB: As to the question of terrorism, Australia, of course, condemns terrorism wherever and whenever it occurs. We have been aware for many years of allegations of Iranian support for terrorist attacks against various targets. But available evidence of a direct Iranian role, as distinct from the role of Iran-supported organisations, and evidence of direct high level government support for such attacks, has been extremely limited. In the event that more such evidence were to be forthcoming and, in particular, any evidence suggesting any change for the worse in Iranian behaviour, we would obviously have to reconsider our position on the whole bilateral relationship.

It always remains a matter for judgment whether states and regimes whose international behaviour or respect for human rights is borderline or worse will behave better or worse when confronted with a cessation of diplomatic relations or economic relations, trade sanctions and the like. In this respect, much depends, among other things, on how universally applied, how comprehensive in scope and how long sustained the international reaction is. There are always some countries which respond better to carrots than to sticks.

The only further thing I can say is, notwithstanding the recent United States announcement, we, in common with many other countries in Europe and elsewhere, have not been inclined to change our present policy towards Iran. Nonetheless, that policy will be kept under close review in the light of ongoing developments.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer to a recent three-month survey of 12 child-care centres which found that an average of 10 children were left in child care each day with illnesses such as meningitis, measles, diarrhoea and upper respiratory tract infections, and that the centres took 25 children to hospitals with serious illnesses. Is it true, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday, that the minister has confirmed that Mr Keating has decided to break his 1993 election promise and will not spend $15.7 million on special child care for sick children? Should Australian families also assume that Mr Keating will break his revised 1994 promise to spend $7 million on a plan for family day care workers to come to parents' homes to care for sick children? Is this not just one more broken promise in a very long list of broken promises and a further indication that we cannot trust Mr Keating when he makes election promises, just as we cannot trust his fudged budget figures?

—Most of that question does not deserve an answer because it goes to abuse of the Prime Minister and contains all those usual expected things that the opposition will trawl about. Senator Patterson knows as well as I that some of it goes to what may or may not be in the budget. Again, I am not going to say anything about that.

PARA.TAB: As to the serious point about the best way to deal with sick children in child care, which was made in the middle of all that abuse and rubbish, that has been a matter of the gravest concern for government. I think Senator Patterson knows that, because we have had a number of investigations and inquiries into it. The issues have been canvassed with parents. They say that, as the highest priority, the best way they would like to see sick children dealt with—in particular, their own sick children—is in the familiar place that those children know best, their home. Secondly, the examination of how best to deal with the matter of sick children raised very difficult issues of protocols for admission to child-care centres—protocols for what constituted disease, how best to manage it all, and so on.

Thirdly, as you would know I made a decision to defer the examination of the care program for sick children, pending the outcome of the test leave case in the Industrial Relations Commission. In the light of all of that, I think the need for child care to be provided at home remains. The difficulty with protocols and risks of cross-infection remain. In the light of all the information, I would have to say that it is unlikely that the program will proceed. I have noticed that article, and I am certainly going to seek further information about it because it does raise very important issues. I will be seeking a full briefing on Senator Patterson's question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald stated:

PARA.TAB: A spokeswoman for Senator Crowley yesterday confirmed that the scheme "is not going to go ahead".

QUESTION.PARA: Is the report right or wrong?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have nothing further to add to what I have just said.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. The minister would be aware of the article in today's Canberra Times which highlights the significant increase in Australia's research and development. Can the minister explain the implications of this increase and, in particular, comment on the large rise in business expenditure on R&D?

—Senators would be aware that one of the signs of a growth economy is the amount of investment in research and development. In pairing science and technology capability with research and development capability, you drive economic growth. The figures that have been referred to in the article in the Canberra Times demonstrate unequivocally that the government's policies are working in encouraging investment overall in research and development, and particularly private investment in research and development.

PARA.TAB: The figures show that in 1992-93 Australia's aggregate spending on research and development had risen to $6.3 billion, an increase of 16 per cent in real terms in just two years. As a percentage of GDP, our R&D spending now stands at an all-time high of 1.56 per cent, an improvement on a figure of about one per cent in the early 1980s when the coalition was in power. We have gone from one per cent to 1.56 per cent, an all-time record in terms of expenditure on research and development in Australia.

In the early 1980s, Australia's gross expenditure on R&D as a proportion of GDP ranked us No. 16 on the OECD table. Australia has now jumped three slots and, as a consequence, is now ranked overall at No. 13. We have jumped ahead of nations such as Canada and New Zealand and are reeling in fairly quickly the United Kingdom which, in fact, has seen a decline—and a significant one—in overall expenditure on research and development, obviously reflecting the attitudes of a conservative government and the sorts of economic policies pursued in the United Kingdom that have sabotaged the very fine reputation that nation has enjoyed as a site for high science and technology and for research and development.

Expenditure on research and development in Australia over the relevant period has grown faster than in any other OECD country. It reflects that we have the fastest growth of any OECD country in the registration of patents. That reflects a growing innovation culture in Australia and a growing recognition in our private sector of the strength of our basic long-term fundamental scientific research. It also reflects the beginning of a wedding between the private sector short-term applied research and the long-term fundamental capability that Australia has as a leading science nation in the world.

If one looks at public sector expenditure on research and development in the OECD table, one sees that Australia, which was formerly ranked seventh, is now ranked fourth. It came up three slots. Only the Nordic countries—Sweden, Finland and Norway—spend more public dollars on research and development as a percentage of GDP than does Australia. We outrank all other OECD countries—including the United States, Germany and Japan—in terms of public expenditure.

The strong performer in changing these figures is the Australian business community. In comparing 1981 to 1992, we had the highest growth rate in the OECD, but in the two years from 1992 to 1993 business expenditure on research and development in Australia grew by 28 per cent. Higher education expenditure on research and development in the same period grew by 22.6 per cent but state government expenditure on research and development declined by 8.6 per cent. Everyone else is pulling their weight in terms of developing an innovation culture in Australia in the lead-up to the innovation statement, but the state governments seem to have forgotten their responsibilities in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister in his reply referred to the development of an innovation culture in Australian business. Can the minister explain how the innovation statement will help develop that culture and make a difference to Australian industry?

—The government has indicated it will bring down a formal statement on innovation in around August this year. As a consequence of setting ourselves that task, which is directed to making Australia the premier location for science, technology, engineering and innovation in the Asia-Pacific region, we have been in consultation with all of Australian industry on a sectoral basis. Each industry sector has been consulted. Over a thousand people have been spoken to directly. Our science community, many of our primary researchers, institutes and the CSIRO have been consulted.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday I released a report which contains all of the recommendations the Australian community has made about inventing an innovation culture for Australia. This will be important feedstock for the innovation statement when we bring it down in August. Members of the opposition have interjected. Let me say that our record compared to theirs is so outstanding they are not even in the debate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the minister aware that a small group of British parliamentarians attending official Turkish ceremonies commemorating the 80th anniversary of the Gallipoli landings on 25 April were asked by Australian Foreign Affairs officials not to attend the Australian-organised dawn service at Anzac Cove on the grounds that there would not be enough room for them on the beach? In view of the concerns expressed publicly by one of these politicians in an article in last week's Spectator magazine and by others privately to me and other Australian parliamentarians attending the ceremony, will the minister assure the Senate that this request was not government policy? Will he assure the UK parliament that no offence was intended and confirm that Australia honours not only the 7,800 Anzacs but also the 25,000 British troops killed in this campaign, along with the tens of thousands more from other Commonwealth and allied countries such as Canada, France, India and Pakistan?
—I am not aware of any such request having been made. I will add that to the pile of information that I have been seeking about various other aspects of the conduct of these Anzac Day proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Certainly it is not government policy to suggest that in any way the attendance of British representatives would be inappropriate on that occasion. The British were obviously a very major component of the Gallipoli peninsula landings and a great many British soldiers fought honourably and died in that ill-fated campaign. If any offence was caused, it certainly was not intended.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister very much for that assurance which I naturally expected. While he is inquiring into this matter, could he also assure the Senate that the failure to have any traditional hymns, such as Abide With Me, at either of the two Australian-run Gallipoli ceremonies was also not government policy and that any such future ceremonies will return to the traditional form of Australian dawn services?
—I have no information on that matter. I will certainly make that the subject of further inquiry.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to the assessment by the World Bank reported in the Australian Financial Review of 7 April, and I have carefully noted the minister's comments on that. I refer to the reference in that report to the fact that gains in agricultural trade expected from the Uruguay Round of GATT are being subverted by most countries maintaining their barriers and subsidies and that, as a result, Australia's income gain will drop from 0.6 per cent to 0.1 per cent of GDP—in other words, in effect, to zero. Now that the minister has had time to reflect on this report, and since he has justified decimating the Australian citrus industry, among others, by promising large gains for Australian agriculture as a whole, I ask: what specific measures is the minister taking to keep his promise and to protect and advance the interests of Australia's primary producers?

—I thank Senator Spindler for his question. The broad response to the World Bank report is one which I gave earlier to Senator Margetts; but let me deal with the specifics. There was nothing in the World Bank report that came as a surprise. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics made it very clear that the assumptions used in the paper prepared for the World Bank are virtually the same as those which it used.

PARA.TAB: ABARE and the Australian government were aware during the course of the negotiations that the three economic units to which I refer—the United States, the European Union and Japan—were seeking to minimise the concessions they had to make. One of the processes by which that took place was the so-called dirty tariffication. This is not a revelation. It is something which we do not welcome; but it is part of the process by which they sought to minimise the extent to which trade was opened up.

Notwithstanding the resistance of those units to the proper processes of agricultural reform, which we will continue to pursue through the Cairns Group and in other ways, there are still substantial benefits for Australian agriculture. The Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has made it very clear; there is not any doubt about it. We can speculate about econometric models in some circumstances and say, `Maybe this has not measured it correctly,' but we cannot by any process of measurement deny the fact that when we can sell into a market which was previously denied we have made a benefit.

I was talking with members of the citrus industry yesterday. One of the benefits for the citrus industry that we were talking about was the agreement by Korea to allow into its market 15,000 tonnes of oranges per year—if I recall the figures correctly—and the possibility of significant new markets for the citrus industry in Thailand and Taiwan. So there are significant benefits. They are benefits which are not as significant and as substantial as they should have been but this is not something that has occurred since the Uruguay Round; it is something of which we were aware. There continue to be activities by the major economic groupings of the European Union and major nations such as the United States which may circumvent, at least temporarily, the full benefits which should flow to Australia and other fair traders in agriculture.

There will be another meeting of the Cairns Group this month in Manila and we—Australia and other members of that group which are fair traders in agriculture—will continue to pursue our collective objective of freer and fairer trade in agriculture through domestic agricultural reforms in the European Union, the United States and Japan; through multilateral measures; and through regional initiatives like APEC which, if they succeed in accordance with our aspirations and the Bogor declaration, will also generate substantial opportunities for Australian agriculture.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for the generalities he has offered but we cannot get away from the fact that from 0.6 per cent of GDP we are realising gains of only 0.1 per cent. That is an 80 per cent drop in the expected benefits that the World Bank found in its assessment. The specific question is: how does the minister explain this? Other countries are not meeting their obligations. What is he going to do about the other countries that are not meeting their obligations to desist in subsidising exports—the United States has continued to subsidise them—hitting our farmers to leg?

—While it is true that the United States continues to subsidise its agricultural exports more than it should, the only constraint on the extent to which it does so is the agreement under the Uruguay Round, and that will start to take effect from 1 July. Those constraints will be of significant benefit to Australian agriculture. I have not been able to study in full the World Bank report.
—Well, you should.

—The copy has not been made available to me, so it makes it a little hard. One of the important things which does not appear to be covered in the initial assessment which I have been able to make is the benefit to Australian agriculture of the constraint upon agricultural subsidies. They were measuring the fact that, had it not been for this so-called dirty tariffication, the reduction in tariffs on agriculture in the major markets would have been of even greater benefit to Australia than it is. That is true. We would have liked to have gained more. That is why, through the Cairns Group, we have made it very clear that we and those countries will not agree to another round of trade liberalisation negotiations without agriculture.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the minister aware that a scientific report by the CSIRO has identified up to eight highly contagious diseases in Canadian and United States salmon which the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has just approved for importation into Australia? Do you care that an outbreak of just one of those diseases could wipe out Tasmania's growing salmon industry, worth an estimated $100 million a year, and 2,000 jobs in the aquiculture industry? How much compensation will the federal government offer Tasmanian salmon growers for the losses they suffer because of diseases introduced by imported Canadian and US salmon products? What action will the minister take to ensure that this outstanding export industry is not gutted by the decision by AQIS to lift its ban on imported salmon from North America?

—I have been told by quite a number of representatives from Tasmania, including Senator Nick Sherry, that this matter is of great importance to Tasmania. I therefore ask Senator Newman how she could get it so horribly, drastically wrong. The question is so breathtakingly inaccurate that it is not funny. I am sure that Senator Calvert and others realise how utterly wrong it is.

PARA.TAB: There has been no decision by AQIS to do the things that Senator Newman has just suggested it has done. The question is totally, utterly wrong. What has happened is that AQIS has released its draft import risk analysis in the normal way on the importation of uncooked, wild harvested, ocean caught pacific salmon from the USA and Canada.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hello, Robin.

—Yes, hello Robin Gray. All interested parties have until 10 July to advise AQIS of any technical concerns related to quarantine risks. The import risk analysis, recognising Australia's excellent disease status, recommends that the importation of salmon products be allowed provided certain requirements—
—There you are.

—for certification processing are implemented. If you cannot tell the difference between what I am saying and what Senator Newman has asserted, you should go back to school. On this basis, there would be negligible risk of introduction of disease that could affect aquiculture or recreational fishing. AQIS has incorporated scientific advice from CSIRO's Animal Health Laboratory in its risk analysis. It is not true that AQIS has ignored or suppressed the CSIRO advice.

PARA.TAB: While AQIS's conclusion depends to a small extent on a judgment about the probable effectiveness of screening of fish by Canadian suppliers as a means of excluding disease, many factors were taken into account with the analysis. I repeat: there has been no decision by AQIS to allow the importation of salmon. By the way, Robin Gray is coming to see me shortly with a delegation of salmon growers from Tasmania. He knows that the interim risk analysis—that is, the draft which has been issued—has 60 days for a response from industry or from any other interested persons, including yourself, Senator Newman, before any such decision will be taken.

No such decision has been taken by AQIS. You will have your chance, Senator Newman, along with everyone else in the next 60 days to put your views to AQIS. Why don't you join the delegation that Robin Gray is leading to see me in a few days, Senator Newman?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I understand that the minister is aware of concerns raised by a number of small businesses about the effect of large retailers, particularly supermarkets, on the viability of these small businesses. Could he inform the Senate as to what action the government intends taking on this matter?

—It is true that a number of small independent retail traders in recent times in the Hunter Valley have raised with the government the difficulties they face in competing with large supermarkets, particularly where the large supermarkets are engaged in a price war to increase their own market share.

PARA.TAB: Issues, of course, such as planning approvals and extended trading hours, are state matters and local government matters and are not within the constitutional power of the federal government. However, one area in which the Commonwealth government does have responsibility is the Trade Practices Act and whether the activities of supermarkets contravene the powers under the Trade Practices Act.

In particular, section 46 of the act prohibits misuse of market power and section 51AA prohibits corporations from engaging in unconscionable conduct—conduct that is unconscionable within the meaning of the unwritten law of Australia's states and territories.

In the case of some particular practices of supermarkets in the Hunter region in the issue of market power, the TPC found no evidence to suggest other than legitimate competitive market conduct. The TPC found that there was intense competition between major supermarkets and that this was having a fallout on the smaller players. Of course, I do not think anybody here would oppose fair and vigorous competition in the marketplace.

However, in this context, I think senators would recall that some years ago in the early 1990s, the unconscionable conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act were amended and strengthened and this is being looked at by members of the small business forum and the small business coalition in Australia, to see whether these new powers of unconscionable conduct can be used by small businesses to protect themselves from the activities of large corporations—for example, supermarkets active in the Hunter Valley.

Under my suggestion at the end of last year the small business forum established a subcommittee to look at whether they could find cases that the TPC could take on on behalf of small business to test the unconscionable conduct powers. That subcommittee of the small business forum, representing 31 small business organisations, reported back to the small business forum and to myself, saying that contrary to the expectations at the time, they believe that the present power of unconscionable conduct, even as amended—only some three years ago—is extremely limited in its application and is not addressing the problem as small business sees it.

The working party recommends that section 51AA be amended to broaden its application and provide redress for small business. I have asked the working party on behalf of the small business forum, the 30-odd small business organisations, to indicate whether the small business organisations they represent themselves would publicly support such an amendment to the Trade Practices Act on unconscionable conduct, which I have no doubt would be a matter of some controversy in the business community.

I am now receiving indications that a number of small business organisations would support such a change, but other organisations are doubtful about supporting that change. However, when I get the full report and response from the small business forum, the government will then consider that report and how much support there is in the small business community for such a change to strengthen unconscionable conduct to help small business in Australia.
