DEBATE.TITLE: DEPUTY PRESIDENT AND CHAIRMAN OF COMMITTEES

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This is a melancholy moment and a matter of some sadness upon which I am required to comment. So far I have, by and large, refused to respond to the press save for, I think, three innocent occasions where I sought to ensure that neither my family nor the Liberal Party was damaged. I do not propose to deal with the internal Liberal Party machinations, as the expression is these days, which no doubt will be dealt with by the party.

PARA.TAB: It will come as no surprise to know that I could have indulged myself, as could my wife—who is in the gallery today—with the 60 Minutes program or the Sunday program. One of my colleagues appeared on the Sunday program and I seem to be the recipient of his comments. No member of our family has agreed to interviews by the popular women's magazines such as the Womens' Weekly, Woman's Day or New Idea. Representatives of those magazines seemed to think that this is some sort of interesting story for them.

The reasons for our refusal to be interviewed are pretty simple. We are a very private family and we think that this is a very private matter. We do not intend to score votes for ourselves; nor do we seek self-indulgence; nor do we seek sympathy; nor do we seek to make political points. We took the view that this matter should never have been raised, it should never have been used in the way in which it has been used, and it should never, under any circumstances, have led to this situation.

The circumstances of my resignation are now a matter of public record. It is not without significance to note that this cheap dirt which was circulated about me came after I attracted—I might say modestly—90 per cent of the votes of my colleagues at my preselection. With the exception of one other occasion when I received 109 votes out of 118, that is the best vote that any senator has ever received in Western Australia for Senate preselection.

Mr President, I understand how you feel about these things. I wish you could have had my vote. However, when you cannot win by legitimate means in the game and the art of politics, you win by illegitimate means. That has been the matter that I have had to deal with.

The facts of the matter are quite simple and I want honourable senators to reflect upon them for a moment. It was a domestic incident about which nobody has the awareness, the understanding, the knowledge of the circumstances leading up to it, or the manifestation of it. Some 5 1/2 years ago my wife was advised by a lawyer to seek a restraining order. When she understood the implications of the restraining order, and when she had time for a moment of reflection, she promptly had it withdrawn. It was never served on me and it was never enforced. It was ex parte and it was simply nothing more than a piece of paper. But, as a result of that, I stand before the Senate as an ex-deputy president.

The Sydney Morning Herald, for reasons best known to itself—they are pretty well known to most of us—runs campaigns against certain individuals. I happen to be one of them. Today's paper describes me as a wife basher. People who know the facts, the circumstances, the incident, the occasion and the events would want to vomit upon reading it. That is the reason for my resignation from the deputy presidency.

I seek not to be melancholy, but there is a matter I have to touch upon. The day the dirt sheet was distributed was the day I was in Geraldton with my wife burying her father. The disclosure of the matter by a senior Liberal lawyer, who was indirectly involved in the matter, is another matter. No doubt another forum will contemplate it. But that is not my business; it is the business of other people.

This has been a uniquely private matter for our family, as were the circumstances leading up to it and the family's involvement in it. This resignation raises the question of what are private affairs of people and families and what is of public interest. When a circumstance in my private family that was resolved and reconciled 5 1/2 years ago—we have always been a close family, however we lead our lives—ventures into the public arena, others will have to deal with it. Reconciliation and a sense of warmth, growth and strength can occur in a family after it resolves a matter which arose because of unique circumstances. If once it is resolved and satisfied it becomes a matter of public indulgence to be commented upon by the press and parliamentarians, that begs a whole range of questions.

To use a terrible expression, I am not in the business of `outing' anybody. I am sorry that Senator McMullan is not here today, because he is one person who has attacked me about it publicly. This will visit in the imminent future not only the Liberal Party but also the Labor Party. I am not saying that in a tempting way. However, there are certain matters upon which a number of us have had knowledge for a very long time.

It is no secret that I have always attacked the arguments and policies and not the personalities. I am sure that Senator Hill will not mind telling the Senate of a circumstance recently where I argued with some passion in the party room that we should not be attacking the President. There was also another occasion recently—I am sure that my other colleagues will not mind telling the Senate about it—when I argued with some passion that we should not be attacking one Labor Party person about a matter which I did not believe related to his duties and responsibilities.

It gave me no comfort to have the Sydney Morning Herald ring me the next day to confirm whether I was arguing against this proposition, as if it were some sin. I simply do not believe that one can inexorably marry personal and public affairs simply in the interests of winning political votes. If we are in that game, we are no better than second-hand car salesmen. I hope that I do not offend them by saying that.

For the record, in essence I have felt very touched and, frankly, very moved by the support I have received from the Labor Party, from a number of its ministers and from the Democrats on this matter. Their judgment was that this was not a matter visited upon me in respect of my contribution as a senator, as the Deputy President of the Senate and—our god willing, Mr President—maybe as the President of the Senate. I want to make sure that that is clearly understood.

This attack does not have universal appeal. This rather unsavoury salivation by the press is not just a burden for me but it has been a torment and a torture for my wife and three innocent, pristine children. The question I ask, not in a rhetorical sense, is: what has been the sin that they have committed which has required them to carry this particular burden? They were not privy to my decision to enter parliament, save for one, I think. Perhaps we had two children at the time; I cannot remember. They did not have a say in my decision to enter parliament.

My wife said to me recently, `Noel, I never wanted you to go into parliament, but you never really consulted me. I just took it that that was what you wanted to do and it was my responsibility to allow you to fulfil the obligations you felt you had to both the Liberal Party and the wider community.' I do not seek to protect myself behind my family, but this begs the question as to what is a public matter and what is a private matter.

Do I in future make an issue as to whether someone in this chamber is a homosexual or not? Do I make an issue as to whether or not one of my colleagues happens to be a lesbian? Do I make an issue as to whether or not members of the press gallery are having affairs with ministers of state or with members of the frontbench of the opposition? Are they issues that go to the heart and touch upon your capacity and ability to discharge responsibilities and duties? I do not know, but it is important that we ask ourselves the question as to what is a public matter and what is a private matter. It seems to me that we are going down the road of the American system, where much of what is raised has absolutely nothing to do with one's character, ability, responsibility or capacity to discharge one's responsibilities but is simply idle, dirty gossip for the sheer fun and fascination of a public which will always find such matters inviting.

For me, entering the Senate and entering parliament was simply an utter indulgence of my own. It gave no financial benefit to my family. I can tell you that it has cost them an absolute fortune. It has meant that I have spent much of my time away from my family, but it was something I decided to do and something they sacrificed. That is why I raise the question as to what price they have to pay for my having made the decision I did and then being prepared to carry that sacrifice.

However, as we all know these days, altruism is simply seen as a cynical exploitation of personal naked ambition. No longer can people be seen to be going into parliament, into politics or into public affairs without some personal political gain or some personal ambition to be fulfilled.

We are and always have been a very private family. I am very tempted not to say this, but I have to tell the chamber something so that senators can understand the level of this debate. I had a son who strangled in his cot when he was two years, two months and two weeks of age. He was being baby-sat by my wife's parents.

Evangelical Christians these days have a more relaxed attitude about Sunday afternoons but, on that Sunday afternoon, my wife's view was that we should not be involving ourselves, or that she at least should not be going out on a Sunday afternoon to what one might describe as a frivolous social occasion. I insisted we go because it was a fundraising function for Peter Shack. When we came home my son was dead on his bed because his restraining strap had caught him around the throat. He had climbed out of his cot and strangled himself.

I tell that story for only this reason. Within the last two weeks somebody in the Liberal Party has suggested to the press that they should go to the Attorney-General's Department and dig out the file on my son's autopsy to see how he really died. There was no inquest, of course; there was an autopsy which Esther and I asked for.

Those of you who have read an autopsy report will understand the trauma that took place in this parliament in the last week of the sittings when Senator Rosemary Crowley was under attack for mistakenly releasing some documents. I understood that drama and trauma better than anybody else because I have read two autopsy reports, that of my sister and that of my son, and I knew the implications of what had been released on that occasion.

I tell the Senate this for no other reason than for honourable senators to understand the level to which politics is capable of sinking. My wife was in a public phone box when she heard that information, and the fact she collapsed should come as no shock to anyone. It is not difficult to understand the effect that this whole saga has had upon our family.

Can I just touch upon one other quite unrelated matter. Recently I have read in the press that Noel Ashley Crichton-Browne is in some way a liability to the Liberal Party in Western Australia. I do not want to indulge myself, but I do want to put on public record for the benefit of the family that for 10 years of my life I worked full time in a voluntary capacity for the party. I drew no salary; I drew no costs; I drew no benefits; I drew no rewards. I simply did it because I had a commitment. Coming into parliament was not part of my program; it was not part of my agenda. I simply did it because I thought it was part of the contribution that our family should make. Simple arithmetic will tell you what I was capable of earning and what it cost us as a family over those 10 years.

Today I rang Western Australia to ask what my record was. I was reminded that when I ran the campaign in 1977 Charles Court got 54 per cent of the vote—the highest vote the Liberal Party had ever recorded. You can tell me there are a thousand reasons why we did it, but there always are when you win. I started the Kalgoorlie North division of the Liberal Party and we held every single seat north of the 26th parallel. I do not know who has been north of the 26th parallel in Western Australia besides Senator Cook and Senator Chris Evans, but it is a pretty hard grind. We held all those seats in areas which might be equated to Mount Isa, Gladstone or Port Kembla because we had the infrastructure on the ground and the capacity, the facility and the ability to win.

In 1975 we won nine out of 10 seats in WA when I ran the campaign. In 1977 we won nine out of 10 seats in Western Australia when I ran the campaign and we went within 2,000 votes—as John Dawkins well remembers—of winning the seat of Fremantle. I do not take any pride in telling the Senate that when I was asked to run the recent Helena by-election in Western Australia, it was the first time since 1951, and the only other occasion since Federation, that a government has won a seat from the opposition. At the last state election, which I had the dubious distinction of also managing, we won 55.4 per cent of the vote—the highest vote the Liberal Party has ever received in Western Australia. I put those things on the record not for me—because it does not matter—but for those people who do care and who do know.

In concluding, I thank you, Mr President, for the support you have always given me and I thank those who have spoken kindly and in an indulging way today. I also thank those who saw fit, whether they be ministers of the Crown or from other political parties, to ring me and ask me not to resign as the Deputy President but to stay in that position because there was no way they would move upon me. I thank my colleagues who voted for me last time and who, presumably, given an opportunity, may have voted for me again. I thank the Senate for its indulgence.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a regurgitation of the assertions made by the opposition during question time. At that time they were wrapped in the form of a question; they are now wrapped in the form of a direct statement. Neither form is true; both are wrong. Nonetheless, the opposition, which obviously seeks comfort in trying to besmirch the reputation of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and paint him as something he is not, and which seeks comfort as well in any figures it can find—no matter how arcane they might be—that reflect in any way on Australia's economic performance, is taking comfort in trying to argue the case that the economy is in bad shape and, therefore, the opposition should be elected to government.

PARA.TAB: This is a preposterous fallacy, one that anyone who knows anything about the Australian economy would see through instantly. But since the opposition does it constantly, one imagines it is for the reason that if enough mud is thrown at someone, some of it will stick and, therefore, the reputation of the Prime Minister and the efficacy of the economy will be undermined.

I saw the Four Corners program last night. I heard Tony Cole say some things about the forecasted figures in the One Nation statement and I read the article in the Australian yesterday by the correspondent who interviewed him. I did not hear Tony Cole saying that the Prime Minister in any way was responsible for changing the figures. That is an allegation made by the opposition; it is not an allegation or a comment made by Mr Cole. It would be refreshing if one debated this matter on a factual basis; not on a basis of allegation or of reputation besmirching.

The answer given by Senator Gareth Evans in question time today was accurate in every respect. There is a body within the Commonwealth government called JEFG, the Joint Economic Forecasting Group. It is a body drawn from a number of Commonwealth government agencies as well as departments, whose job it is to forecast the directions of the economy and to provide advice to the government on what those forecasts are. Traditionally and typically, it forecasts half-yearly and yearly.

The One Nation statement was not a budget in which the forecasts would have been geared to inform the government. It was a one-off statement made, as I recall, in January or February of 1991. It was made as a countercyclical statement to put growth back into the economy. It worked. The growth figures that we are experiencing—the decrease in unemployment, the increase in profit share—show that the countercyclical measures used by the government actually worked. That is not the point of what the opposition raises here.

In order to frame such a document, the government had to turn to estimates of future growth. What JEFG had forecast was in its typical yearly and half-yearly review periods. What the One Nation statement—falling at an odd time—required was medium-term forecasts. In order to get a medium-term forecast that JEFG was not geared to provide, on page 120 of One Nation you will find reported to the public at large the committee that assessed the measures being applied in One Nation. Since they were stimulus measures, you also find what additional benefit or growth to economy those stimulus measures would produce. Because you had a regular cycle forecast, you were operating at an odd time. You assembled a body of Treasury, PM&C and ministerial officials to provide the necessary information for the forecasts. That is all reported. It is in the papers of One Nation. If you argue it, have a look at the papers. That is what happened.

There was dispute within that committee, but every member of that committee signed off on the recommendation in the end. It is no news to this place that there are disputes in committees; it happens all the time. But the members reconciled themselves, agreed and signed off on it. So let us not have this smear that somehow the Prime Minister involved himself in baking the books. He did not. Anyone who proposes that is not telling the truth.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: The second thing that has changed is predatory pricing. This has come in a disturbing way in many areas of the Hunter, where big chain stores have forced out of business nearby small businesses by reducing prices for a sustained period. When the other small businesses have gone broke, they have gone back to their old pricing systems. The effect of this in an area like the Hunter is quite devastating. We have at the moment one business closing a day.

There is a very wide range of types of businesses affected by this. Fruit shops, chemists, delicatessens, bakeries, butcheries and take-away food outlets are all being affected by these policies. Recently in the suburb of Mayfield a brand new chain store opened, and the effect on the surrounding shops has been quite devastating. The business that probably finds it most difficult of all to compete with the chains is fresh fruit. Many other businesses, such as pharmacists, can provide specialist services that the chains cannot, but it is difficult in the area of fresh food such as fruit.

In this case I went into this man's fruit shop in Merewether. It was a very big fruit shop; it was a very professionally run business. But the fact was he was losing money in that shop. He supplied the naval ships that went into Newcastle and that was the area from which he got his profit to subsidise his shop. If this man who is such an efficient businessman cannot make a go of it, no wonder one shop a day is shutting in the Hunter.

The business operators in the Hunter became so concerned about this that they held a meeting recently where 500 people turned up. The local Labor members were not very helpful in their response at that time and so they wrote to Minister Schacht, who is the minister for small business. And this was his reply:

SPEECH.PARA: It is often a regrettable consequence of major retailers engaging in price wars that smaller businesses cannot compete.
While I sympathise with your situation, it would be inappropriate for the Commonwealth Government to establish mechanisms that reduce competition in the marketplace.

It would seem that the changing face of retailing, and the move away from specialty stores to large "one-stop" shopping centres that cater for the normal buying needs of the community, has impacted significantly on small businesses. This is regrettable. However, the changes in shopping behaviour are the result of changes in the nature of society, with greater demands for convenience and range to reflect different lifestyles. Unfortunately, it is the larger supermarkets who are best placed to meet these new demands.

That is a very unsympathetic response. Fortunately, since that time and since representations I have made, the minister has been prepared to meet a delegation from the small business people in the Hunter. We believe that they are being targeted as part of a lead campaign which will then spread through the rest of Australia and affect businesses in the rest of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I want this minister to sit down with the people of the Hunter who can tell him not only how this is affecting their businesses and their lifestyle but how it is affecting the employment opportunities for young people in a region of high unemployment. I realise that some areas with which this matter is concerned, such as trading hours, are the province of state governments—and state governments urgently need to look at trading hours. This minister should convene the ministerial council to discuss how these things can be changed.

But within the Trade Practices Commission the minister has more power than he is letting on. Let us see a real attempt to try to improve the situation for small business who do not mind competing. But they want to compete on a level playing field and they are not getting it under the present regime. Let the minister come and listen. Let the minister change the law so that these people can compete and survive.(Time expired)

Dear Sir

I refer to a letter dated 28 February from the Chairman, the Honourable Senator Mal Colston in respect of Statutory Rules No 464 of 1994, being amendments to the Rules of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

The Committee seeks my advice on the legality and appropriateness of the Commission requiring applicants for certified agreements and enterprise flexibility agreements to specify employees beyond the three statutory categories to be found in the Industrial Relations Act 1988, and also on the lack of certainty involved in requiring the identification of other employees whose interests may not have been taken into account.
Section 48 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 enables me, after consultation with members of the Commission, to make rules with respect to:

PARA.TAB: the practice and procedure to be followed in the Commission; or
the conduct of business in the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Both sections 170MG and 170NG require the Commission to identify "relevant employees" whose interests may not have been sufficiently taken into account in the negotiations for, or the terms of, the agreement. Both sections provide examples of three categories of employees whose interests may not have been taken into account.

As you are aware, subsection 15AD(a) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 provides that where an Act includes an example of the operation of a provision, the example shall not be taken to be exhaustive.

It was evident from the consultation process conducted with members of the Commission that information in respect of the additional categories of employees that the Rules now require was necessary for the Commission to satisfy its obligations under section 170MG in respect of certified agreements and section 170NG in respect of enterprise flexibility agreements.

Additionally, the inclusion of specific categories within the Rules would largely ameliorate the very lack of certainty involved in requiring the identification of employees (other than the three examples contained in the statute) whose interests may not have been taken into account.

Nevertheless, it was recognised that the Rules could not make reference to each and every category of "relevant employee". For this reason, the Rules continue to require applicants to identify employees who might be "relevant employees" but are not included in the specified classes of employees. Taking into account the additional classes of employees now specified in the Rules, I did not consider it inappropriate that applicants continue to be required to identify other "relevant employees".
Yours sincerely

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 (the act) is part of a global network of legislation, with the goal of protecting biological diversity and maintaining ecological processes and systems.

The proposed amendments will enhance the extent to which Australia discharges its obligations under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) and the Convention on Biological Diversity. The amendments will provide an improved administrative framework, strengthen measures against illegal wildlife trafficking, and make the Australian Nature Conservation Agency's service to client groups more effective. They will also support a national approach to the conservation of Australia's biodiversity and improve arrangements for regulating the commercial use of wildlife.

The proposed amendments have been developed after extensive consultations with State and Territory governments, industry and non-government organisations and are in accord with the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment.

The changes have largely arisen from recommendations of the Ley Report which reviewed the act, having particular regard to Australia's obligations under CITES. The proposed amendments will implement Appendix III of CITES, relating to species identified by a Party as under regulation to prevent or restrict exploitation, and needing the co-operation of others in the control of trade. They will also enable a more flexible approach to controlling private non-commercial trade in species identified under Appendix II of CITES, species identified as although not endangered, requiring trade regulation.

A number of wildlife export industries in Australia are subject to the act, which currently provides for the establishment of management and controlled specimens programs, the development of which are undertaken in close consultation with State and Territory agencies. The amendments will include the requirement that any proposals for the commercial utilisation and international trade in native wildlife are subject to appropriate legislative and regulatory regimes in the relevant State or Territory. Management programs may only be approved where the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories is satisfied that to ensure protection of the species, appropriate regulatory measures, monitoring and assessment procedures are in place for the proposed harvesting activity.

Management programs will be subject to time limitations, as it is vital that harvesting of wild native plants and animals are reviewed on a regular basis. Therefore, the amendments will establish a maximum period of five years between such reviews, with the flexibility to establish shorter periods, should it be considered necessary.

Through the introduction of special conditions for permits for export of native animals under interzoological garden transfer, Australian zoos will be better able to manage their animal populations. The well developed Australasian Species Management Program will be assisted by these measures, which will also facilitate participation in international breeding programs involving endangered species.

The risks of detection and prosecution to those associated with wildlife smuggling will increase as a combined result of improved administrative measures and enforcement efforts. Continuation of co-operative work undertaken by the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service, the Australian Customs Service, State and Federal Police, and State wildlife agencies will ensure these changes are effective. Overall, they will improve operating efficiency without compromising the protection of wildlife and the Australian environment.

The proposals include improved enforcement powers of inspectors appointed under the act by strengthening powers of seizure, improving powers of search of premises and conveyances, providing powers to conduct frisk searches of suspect persons, enabling seizure of specimens. These provisions are consistent with the Criminal Code Bill 1994 and the recently amended Crimes Act 1914, while taking into account the rights of the individual. Penalties have also been made consistent with Commonwealth policy regarding introduction of penalty units.

In addition to the substantial penalties currently available for illegally importing and exporting wildlife, the amendments propose a new offence. Any person illegally importing or exporting live animals may be subject to a potential two year imprisonment term, if found guilty of cruel treatment to the animal. This will ensure that the treatment of the animals involved in such crimes is subject to consideration by the courts.

The Government is also concerned that the establishment of self-sustaining populations of exotic birds in the Australian wild could have disastrous effects on native wildlife populations. Further, it may only take one bird infected with an exotic disease, and which has been smuggled into Australia, to contaminate thousands of aviary held or wild native birds. These are serious risks which require a comprehensive approach.

A central measure in the bill to addressing these concerns is the introduction of a national exotic bird registration scheme. The scheme was developed along with close consultation with the aviculture industry, bird keepers and the States and Territories. Registration will provide an inventory of exotic birds currently housed in Australia that have environmental or pest potential, and those that are endangered internationally.

A national inventory created under the scheme will provide an agreed list of exotic birds in Australia that will enable for the first time, the means to properly manage exotic birds. Whilst providing a national focus, the proposed amendments allow the States and Territories the flexibility to impose additional measures if they so desire. The scheme will support and assist the legal trade in exotic birds within Australia. The uncertainty and risks associated with the purchase of many birds will be substantially reduced, by eliminating doubt as to the legal origin of the bird.

An advisory committee to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories will be established to examine the ongoing effectiveness of the registration scheme and to provide advice on proposed variations to the list of birds proposed for registration. This committee will comprise of representatives of government, conservation, and private and professional aviculture.

The Amendment bill also proposes tighter controls on the export of birds as household pets by providing for a limit of two birds that may be taken out of Australia by a person leaving to take up permanent residence overseas.

Additionally, through arrangements being developed under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, international cooperation to stem the illegal wildlife trade has become more effective. Australia has an excellent international reputation for its positive involvement in conservation issues, and will be further extending its support to other countries in this respect, with the creation of a new offence whereby it will be illegal to import wildlife specimens contrary to the conservation laws of a foreign country, where a breach of the overseas law involves trade with Australia and where the foreign country requests assistance. This will enable Australia to assist with international enforcement of wildlife laws of other countries.

Mr President, the environmental problems of the globe, which include a range of threats to biodiversity and the survival of many species of wildlife, will only be addressed through national and international cooperative measures. This Government is providing leadership and support in meeting the national and international challenge of protecting biological diversity and maintaining ecological processes and systems. The Wildlife Protection Amendment Bill is a step forward in meeting that challenge and a further example of the Government's commitment to ensuring an ecologically sustainable future.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: advises people of matters to consider in making decisions about becoming contributors to such funds.

PARA.TAB: We are going through this facade of legislation at the moment when half of it has already been achieved by the industry. TALK.START.PARA: —It was a bit difficult to understand whether Senator Herron's comments were a trawl again over the main points of what he wants to say, including scoring off people in the gallery. PARA.TAB: To pick up on some of the points that you want to raise, Senator Herron, or the points that you thought you scored, if the private health industry is proceeding to achieve some of the things that might be achieved by everybody under this legislation, that ought to be a matter of celebration—not point scoring. The indication by government that it is serious about changes in the private health insurance industry is part of one of the climate changing stages that are very important in assisting the industry through a lot more changes; and doing so with flexibility.

What we are talking about here is a private patients hospital charter to make clear, as Senator Lees said, some information and the rights of patients. We have seen in the past how difficult it is for patients to find out exactly what they are entitled to, exactly what the costs will be, or exactly the details of the procedures they might expect—any of those sorts of things.

This charter says—and its legislation intends—that patients will expect, as a matter of right, to have the information about organisations, hospitals and doctors. It will enable them to make much better, more informed and more sensible decisions about how they want to proceed with any necessary medical or surgical procedure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point seems to have been missed. TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

PARA.TAB: I suggest to Senator Herron that he is undoing his own argument in a way. Not all patients, as Senator Herron acknowledges, will be involved in contracts. They will choose to remain with existing tables and will therefore need additional information. TALK.START.PARA: —There is a lot of ignorance in this debate, and we have had another example of it by Senator Lees. Contracts have existed between full-time specialists and the public hospitals for as long as I can remember. I was one who negotiated them. This will not make any difference whatsoever in relation to private patients in public hospitals. I can understood where it will make a difference, but that is another debate. The debate is in relation to this charter, because it specifically advises people of matters to consider in making decisions about becoming contributors to such funds.

PARA.TAB: The question is: what advice will be given in that charter? For example, will it tell them the various competitive arrangements between differing funds? Does it tell individuals specifically what their likely expenses will be in relation to the nature of the condition for which they are being treated in the private hospital? It seems to be a blanket statement, and I am asking for specifics.

We felt that there could be more of a problem in some city areas where there is a number of hospitals in one location. We see this legislation as working quite well for rural hospitals because, on the information given to us, the funds would be quite keen to make sure they covered a very good geographic spread.

—The point that came out in discussion was that in Western Australia, where there is only one fund, there was no competition available and that would give the fund inordinate control. SPEECH.PARA: It is my privilege to outline to the Senate the budget proposals of the government.
Mr President, this budget has one principal objective: to provide for the continued expansion of the Australian economy.
It will enable the continuation of substantial employment growth, falling unemployment and rising living standards, while reducing pressure on interest rates, inflation and the current account.

It will do so by tackling the major constraint on growth: the long term decline of our national savings. A higher level of national savings will allow higher levels of investment and economic growth without the costs and constraints associated with undue reliance on the savings of foreigners.
This budget provides a two-part plan to improve Australia's saving performance, immediately and over the longer term.
Firstly, it increases public saving.

The budget delivers a surplus in 1995-96 of $718m. This is a massive turnaround in the budget outcome of $12.9 billion or 2.8 per cent of GDP. It is the largest ever turnaround in the budget outcome. It brings the budget into surplus three years earlier than previously forecast.
This is achieved by cuts to spending, increases in revenue and asset sales, including part of the proceeds from the sale of the government's remaining equity in the Commonwealth Bank.
Importantly, the budget for 1996-97 will be in surplus excluding asset sales and special debt and capital repayments.
And the budget surplus by 1998-99 will be $7.4 billion or 1.2 per cent of GDP.

Secondly, the budget will introduce a major increase in private saving in the medium to longer term by the progressive introduction of employee superannuation contributions, with the second round of the One Nation tax cuts paid on a matching dollar for dollar basis into employee superannuation accounts.
Together with the superannuation guarantee and existing award superannuation this initiative will, within a generation, boost Australia's annual saving performance by 4 per cent of GDP.
The return to budget surplus will reduce Commonwealth government debt, which is already well below the average for OECD countries, by almost 30 per cent as a share of GDP over the next four years.
Tonight's budget also addresses immediate high priority needs with new measures for families, health care, the environment and justice.
Mr President, the return of the budget outcome to surplus in 1995-96, and to substantial surplus in 1996-97 and beyond, fulfils the Government's promise to significantly tighten fiscal policy.
The measures announced tonight provide a net fiscal tightening, excluding the effects of asset sales and early debt redemptions, of $3 billion in 1995-96 and $4 1/2 billion in 1996-97.
On the outlays side this tightening has been accomplished by a rigorous examination of all areas of government expenditure.

The decisions the Treasurer is announcing produce a net reduction in outlays of $700 million in 1995-96 excluding asset sales and early debt redemptions. Overall, a real reduction in outlays of 2.5 per cent has been achieved, the first real reduction since 1989-90.
Outlays are projected to fall from 26.7 per cent of GDP in 1994-95 to 24 per cent of GDP in 1998-99, demonstrating the Government's determination to reduce its call on national saving.
Total taxation revenue collected by the Government as a share of GDP declined in each of the 6 years between 1987-88 and 1993-94.
The revenue measures that the Treasurer is announcing tonight strengthen the Commonwealth's tax base and provide a significant contribution to improving the budget outcome.
In all they add $2.4 billion to revenue in 1995-96 and $3.6 billion in 1996-97.

But even after allowing for these measures, budget balance will be restored with revenue much lower, in relation to GDP, than in the past. When we last moved into surplus in 1987-88 revenue represented 27.2 per cent of GDP compared to an estimated 25.3 per cent in 1995-96.
Our fiscal policy compares more than favourably with that of most other industrialised countries and, amongst such countries, we will continue to be one of the lowest taxed.
Mr President, one of the principal objectives of this Budget is to meet the medium term imperative of improving national saving to maintain investment and employment through the 1990s and beyond.

Tonight the Treasurer is announcing, on behalf of the Government, a radical and innovative program to meet that challenge and further decrease Australia's reliance on foreign borrowings. This initiative complements the addition to Australia's savings arising from the budget surplus. It meets a goal and establishes a commitment.
The goal is better retirement incomes for Australians. The commitment, simultaneously established, is to substantially increase the nation's savings.
The measure will build on one of the most far-reaching steps taken during the Government's years of office—the development of Australia's superannuation and retirement incomes policy.

Tonight's announcement will dramatically strengthen and extend that policy. It will not only sharply increase the incomes of Australians in retirement, but will also build a large pool of savings to finance the nation's continuing prosperity.
This initiative has two elements, an employee superannuation contribution and a matching government contribution.
Mr President, in One Nation we said, and I quote:
"The Government will be giving consideration to using employee contributions and tax cuts to increase the total level of superannuation support by a further 3 per cent of earnings."
The Government believes that this is the time to do so—in fact, we believe there is now a need to go beyond the objectives we set then.

Accordingly, under tonight's initiative, the Government will support the inclusion in all awards of provisions for employee superannuation contributions beginning at 1 per cent of earnings in July 1997 and rising to 3 per cent of earnings by July 1999.
This will be timed to coincide with wage increases through enterprise agreements or awards, so that workers will not experience a reduction in disposable income.

The second element, Mr President, is that the Government will match dollar for dollar the contributions paid by most employees into their superannuation accounts—a government contribution, when fully phased in, of $4 billion a year.
By paying the One Nation tax cuts into employees' superannuation accounts we are delivering them in a way that significantly improves national saving.

Together, additional contributions will add 6 per cent of wages to the superannuation of people earning around average incomes. By 2002 this will build on the 9 per cent contribution from employers under the Superannuation Guarantee arrangements.
This new initiative will, therefore, lift the superannuation savings for a person on around average earnings to a minimum of 15 per cent of their wages.
I want to make it abundantly clear, however, that the Government continues to see the age pension as the foundation stone of our retirement incomes policy.
Tonight's arrangements build on the existing pension system.
For a couple on average earnings, now in their mid 30s, the Government's initiatives deliver retirement incomes 75 per cent higher than the age pension.
For their children joining the workforce in the next decade, retirement incomes will be more than double the age pension.
Mr President, the new policy has been designed to benefit low and middle income earners.
Furthermore, employees currently contributing to superannuation will not need to make additional contributions to be eligible for the matching government payment.
The government contribution will be means tested. The Government will match contributions up to a limit of around $1 000 per annum for all workers earning less than around $46 000.
The Government will enable the self-employed to claim the matching government contribution on a proportion of their superannuation savings.
Finally, for equity reasons, the existing means-tested rebate for member contributions will be retained.
Mr President, the policy announced tonight will change forever the expectations of workers as they move towards retirement age.

It will give Australia a comprehensive long-term private savings plan—one that could not have been contemplated without the ground breaking work on superannuation done by this Labor Government since 1983.

I remind honourable members that in 1983, after decades of neglect by the Liberal and National parties, less than 40 per cent of all employees had superannuation coverage. Today, as a result of our reforms, that total is nearly 90 per cent.

For women, the increased coverage from the previous initiatives of this Government has been even more spectacular, rising from 24 per cent in 1983 to 85 per cent today. Thus women now have a major stake in superannuation—and it will be a bigger stake after the Budget's measures.
Today superannuation savings have already reached $186 billion.
But, Mr President, under the policy announced tonight that figure will increase tenfold by the year 2020.

Together with our earlier reforms, tonight's initiatives are estimated to further increase national saving progressively by around 2 per cent of GDP per year by the end of the decade. When fully implemented, they will add 4 per cent of GDP per year to national saving. In today's values that means an increase in saving in the order of $18 billion per annum.
These new superannuation measures will be extremely good for Australian workers and their families, and just as good for the nation.
Mr President, Australia's economy has been growing for 3 1/2 years.
During this time, Australia has had one of the best performing economies among industrialised countries.
In 1994, Australia was among the fastest growing industrialised countries, but with inflation below the average of these countries.
Notwithstanding the severe drought which has affected much of eastern Australia, GDP growth is expected to be 4 3/4 per cent in 1994-95.
And this growth has been broadly based.
Business investment, which has been growing since late 1992, is expected to grow by 18 per cent this fiscal year.
Employment has grown by 4.2 per cent over the 12 months to March 1995.
By delivering around 550 000 new jobs since April 1993, the Government has already surpassed its election commitment to create half a million jobs in this term of office.
As a result, the unemployment rate has fallen to 8.7 per cent.
The number of long term unemployed people has fallen by 25 per cent over the 12 months to March 1995 as the Government's Working Nation program continues to assist them into jobs.
Critical to maintaining this strong growth in activity and employment has been the maintenance of low inflation.
Australia's inflation rate has been below that of our major trading partners over recent years.
Low inflation is the result of reforms to the structure of our economy over the past decade.
A key factor has been the success of the Government's wages policy and industrial relations reforms through the Accord, which is unique to this Labor Government and rejected by the Opposition.
Business is facing an increasingly competitive environment.
With protection reduced and markets opened to competition, businesses are increasingly required to adopt international standards of best practice.
Widespread microeconomic reforms have also resulted in a more competitive economy.

The recent historic agreement between the Commonwealth and the States to implement the national competition policy reforms will, in conjunction with related reforms in industries such as energy and transport, further raise the level of competition in the economy.
All these developments are keeping production costs and therefore inflationary pressures down.
An added benefit of this restraint in prices and wages is that it puts less pressure on monetary policy, and reduces the need for increases in interest rates.
As a result of these improvements in labour and product markets, Australia's international competitiveness is now 18 per cent higher than in the September quarter 1990.

Nevertheless, rapid growth in domestic demand, particularly for investment goods, has led to a sharp rise in imports. In addition, adverse effects on our exports from drought and the hesitant recovery in Japan have increased our current account deficit to an estimated 6 per cent of GDP this year.
Tackling this problem is largely what this Budget is about.
Mr President, in 1995-96 GDP growth will ease from the higher rates recorded in 1994 but will remain strong, at around 3 per cent.
Domestic demand will move more into line with growth in output as a result of:
.a slight moderation in private consumption;
.a continued decline in dwelling investment as housing construction eases back toward underlying demand; and
.a slowing in public demand growth.
Export growth should be rapid as world demand continues to grow strongly and the effects of the drought begin to ease. Reduced domestic demand will lead to a decline in the growth of imports.
Despite an offsetting increase in our net income deficit due to higher world interest rates, the current account deficit is expected to decline by 1/2 per cent of GDP.

Wage growth is expected to be higher in 1995-96 but, in the context of enterprise bargaining and continued improvements in productivity, it should remain compatible with maintaining an underlying inflation rate around 2 to 3 per cent on average over the course of the economic cycle.
This favourable outlook is strongly supported by the union movement's commitment to responsible wage outcomes under the Accord.
And achievement of this goal will be further aided by the spread of enterprise bargaining throughout the workforce.

Employers and employees are taking advantage of the new system by making work practices more flexible, thus improving our productivity performance and providing a firm basis for wage rises for Australian workers.
A new Accord is being negotiated with the ACTU, which will underpin the continuation of responsible wage outcomes and low inflation.
Business investment is expected to remain strong in 1995-96, rising by around 13 per cent.
This will contribute to growth in the capital stock and help maintain economic growth without supply bottlenecks triggering higher inflation.
Employment will continue to grow strongly, by about 3 per cent or over 240 000 jobs.
The unemployment rate should fall to around 8 per cent by mid-1996.
Real household disposable income is forecast to increase by 4 1/4 per cent, following this year's 4 per cent increase.
Mr President, the economic environment facing us over the next few years is one that offers great national opportunities, and great opportunities for all Australians.
This Budget's savings strategy will allow us to maximise these opportunities for economic growth.
Mr President, I now turn to other significant measures in the Budget.
This Budget includes a major statement on our Agenda for Families which responds to the issues raised during the International Year of the Family.
The Government will provide further practical support for families through the initiatives the Treasurer is announcing tonight.
A new means tested maternity allowance of $816 will be introduced from 1 February 1996. It will provide a vital boost to family income when it is most needed: on the birth of a baby.
About 85 per cent of women will be eligible for the payment which will be available to women both at home and in paid employment.

The level of Guardians Allowance paid to sole parent pensioners will be increased by $4 a fortnight from September 1996. Rent assistance will also be increased by $5 a fortnight from March 1996 for families with children.
Both these measures build on significant real improvements in family payments made to low income families over the life of this Government.
From July 1995 the new Parenting Allowance which was announced as part of Working Nation will provide about 115 000 low income working families with an average gain of $59 a week.
Mr President, tonight's Budget also focuses on the health needs of families through preventative health care measures for children and young people.
To raise the immunisation rates among our children and so reduce the incidence of preventable diseases, a National Childhood Immunisation Program costing $11m in 1995-96 will be introduced.
A new `Health Australia' program provides $18m over 3 years for measures to strengthen health promotion and reduce the consumption of tobacco, particularly among young people.
Mr President, the Government will continue to help families meet the challenges faced by competing work and family responsibilities.
The Government will deliver on its 1993 promise to meet the projected demand for work related care by 2000-01.

In this Budget we have taken steps to ensure that the focus is on meeting the needs of working parents, while providing equitable access to subsidised child care for parents who stay at home with their children.
The Government will also provide additional financial support to carers of older people and disabled people, and will promote the role of carers in the community.
A number of the measures to be announced in the Government's forthcoming Justice Statement will help families to avoid legal problems and deal with disputes.

Families of indigenous Australians remain seriously disadvantaged. In this Budget, the Government will build on past initiatives by spending an additional $204m over 4 years to improve the standard of health of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.
Mr President, to reduce spending, the Government looked first at the cost of delivering its own programs.

Indexation arrangements for both Commonwealth Own Purpose Outlays and Specific Purpose Payments to the States with substantial wage costs are to be rationalised from 1 July 1995 producing savings of almost $2 billion over the next 4 years.
The changes will not apply to personal benefit payments—that is, there will be no change to indexation arrangements for pensions, allowances and other income support payments.
Reductions in administrative costs of departments and agencies will produce savings of around $640m over the next 4 years.

Together with a range of efficiency and other measures already adopted by the Government over recent years, this will lead to a reduction in administrative costs of 15 per cent in real terms over the next 4 years.
The Government has also been able to reduce spending on labour market programs.
These savings will not jeopardise achievement of the Government's Working Nation targets. They result largely from more efficient delivery of programs and a stronger labour market.

This Budget also includes measures to simplify the income test applying to pensions through the introduction of a deeming system on financial investments only. It will replace the current system of assessment of unrealised capital growth on shares and managed investments.
The Government will take steps to reduce the rapid escalation of some health program costs.

New arrangements for delivering pathology services and an increase in the safety net threshold for general patients under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme from $407 to $600 from 1 January 1996 will provide substantial savings.
The Government reaffirms its election commitment to support health research by increasing funding for the National Health and Medical Research Council by $58m over 4 years.

Mr President, for the higher education sector there is a budget-neutral package which will provide 5850 new higher education places over the next 3 years and increased funding for research infrastructure.
An additional $217m over 4 years will be provided for initiatives to protect our natural environment, with particular emphasis on our coastline and our native forests.

We will accelerate implementation of the National Forest Policy Statement through a $53m package over 4 years to undertake comprehensive regional forest assessments in five high priority areas and conclude associated regional forest agreements with the States.
The Government also remains determined to improve the urban environment with a further $254m over 4 years for the Better Cities Program.
In a major addition to our transport infrastructure, international and domestic airport facilities will be constructed at Sydney West in time for the Sydney 2000 Olympics.
Tonight the Treasurer is announcing further developments in the Government's asset sales program.
The Government proposes to sell and lease-back DASFLEET's motor vehicle fleet this financial year.
The Government's remaining 50.4 per cent equity in the Commonwealth Bank will be sold in two tranches, one in 1995-96 and one in 1997-98.
The sale will complete the process of putting the ownership of the Bank on a fully commercial basis.
Mr President, the revenue side of the Budget will also play its part in fiscal tightening.
With the strong economic recovery, the corporate profit share has returned to the record levels of the mid 1980s.

Companies in Australia have also benefited from a number of tax concessions in recent years to stimulate business activity. They include investment allowances, accelerated depreciation, the 150 per cent R&D tax concession and a large reduction in the company tax rate from 39 per cent.
These measures will be providing a benefit of more than $3 billion to businesses in 1995-96.
Now that the economy is growing strongly it is appropriate that the corporate sector make a contribution to the tightening of fiscal policy.
Accordingly, the rate of company income tax will be increased from 33 to 36 per cent for the 1995-96 and subsequent income years.
This measure will add $320m to revenue in 1995-96 and $1 570m in 1996-97.
The One Nation statement reduced the wholesale sales tax on passenger motor vehicles by 5 per cent to stimulate demand.
Now that passenger motor vehicle sales are at a high level, it is appropriate to restore the sales tax rate to the general rate of 21 per cent from tonight.

The Government has also decided that, from 1 July 1995, sales tax at the concessional 12 per cent rate will apply to currently exempt builders' hardware and certain building materials used mainly in the completion of buildings.
The bulk of building materials used in construction, such as bricks, timber, cement and roofing tiles, will remain exempt.
Mr President, Medicare levy receipts as a proportion of Medicare outlays have fallen from over 30 per cent in 1988-89 to an expected 24 per cent in 1994-95.
Tonight the Treasurer is announcing an increase in the Medicare levy from 1.4 to 1.5 per cent which will partially reverse this decline.
The excise rate on tobacco will rise by 10 per cent from tonight. This will replace the 5 per cent increase originally scheduled for August 1995.
In recent years evidence has emerged of an erosion of the PAYE tax base, where individuals have attempted to move out of traditional employer/employee relationships in order to avoid tax.

Accordingly, the Government will be amending the income tax law to ensure the intended coverage of the PAYE provisions can be enforced. The Treasurer will also be releasing soon a discussion paper dealing with the use of other schemes to avoid tax on personal services income.

In order to reduce deferral of tax payments under the PAYE system, the threshold at which bi-monthly remittance is required will be reduced to $1m per year. Generally, this measure will affect companies with around 120 employees or more.
To protect the revenue base, the Treasurer is also announcing tonight measures to correct a number of deficiencies in the tax laws.
Eligibility for the research and development tax concession for syndicates investing in private tax exempt bodies will be limited to exclude investors who are not fully at risk.
This measure will prevent inappropriate access to tax benefits, and parallels a 1992 measure applying to public sector tax exempt research bodies.

There will be clarification of certain wholesale sales tax rate classifications including removal of the tax exemption for non-permanent microchips used in certain goods. The current exemption has proved virtually impossible to administer, introduced significant distortions and inefficiencies in the market, and caused considerable loss of revenue.

'Light' fuel oils, which are in effect industrial diesel fuels, will be made subject to excise in the same way as diesel fuels. This is designed to address the tax-driven substitution of `light' fuel oil for diesel which is taking place at some cost to economic efficiency and the environment.

From 1 July 1995, the interest rate which the Reserve Bank of Australia pays banks on their non-callable deposits will be set at 5 percentage points below market rates. This measure recognises the benefits which accrue to banks from being authorised by the Government and subject to RBA prudential supervision.
More detail on each of these and other revenue measures is contained in the budget papers and accompanying statements.
Mr President, tonight's Budget responds to the economic challenges facing Australia today and in the years ahead in a creative and decisive way.
It presents a comprehensive plan to address the deficiency in our national saving.
The immediate restoration of the budget to surplus and the major enhancement to Australia's superannuation arrangements will dramatically boost our savings performance.
At the same time, we have improved the level of social justice so that all Australians benefit from our economic progress.
Over the past dozen years, Australia has undergone a transformation which has made our economy far more competitive, efficient and dynamic than was ever previously imagined.
We are now well placed to capitalise on these improvements.
With continued diligence, hard work, preparedness to change, and intelligent application of our collective skills, we can confidently look forward to a secure and prosperous future for this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 1 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Australian Labor Party's 1993 pre-election 5th term agenda paper for defence science and personnel, entitled The ADF—A Total Family Package:

(1) With reference to the fact that under the heading of housing there is a promise to `Give members with more than six years' service the opportunity to capitalise some of their rental subsidy to be used for a deposit on an occupied own home':
(a) when did the consultants Ernst and Young complete its inquiry into this proposal;
(b) what is the current status of the report;
(c) when will the Government be responding to the report; and
(d) (i) why did the Government engage a consultant to inquire into this proposal,
(ii) why hasn't the Government simply implemented its proposal as promised, and
(iii) how much longer will members of the Defence Force be waiting for this proposal to be implemented.

(2) With reference to the fact that under the heading of child care there is a promise to `examine the possibilities of increasing the number of Defence occasional care centres, in recognition that many spouses stay at home but require short period relief for any number of reasons':
(a) what action has been taken by the Government to meet this promise; if no action has been taken, why not;

(b) if the action identified in (2)(a) is the review of family support services announced in May 1994 by the Minister, was the issue of occasional care centres specifically investigated as part of this review; if not, why not; and
(c) when will the review be completed, and when will the Government be addressing the need for more Defence occasional care centres.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) A comprehensive Review of ADF Housing Policies, completed in June 1993, re-examined 1986 and 1989 Cabinet Decisions concerning the level and form of housing subsidy and choice of housing for ADF members. Following this review, consultant Ernst and Young (Canberra) was contracted to examine the feasibility of a cash subsidy as an alternative to the current methods of delivering housing rental assistance and home ownership assistance to ADF members.
(a) The consultancy commenced in July 1994 and was completed in February 1995.
(b) A final report from Ernst and Young (Canberra) was delivered to the Department of Defence in early February 1995.

(c) The consultant's final report will require detailed study within the Department of Defence and discussion with other agencies before formulation of a formal response which is anticipated in mid-1995.
(d) (i) The consultancy is complex and involves detailed market research and analysis which is beyond Departmental resources.

(ii) The consultancy examined accommodation rental assistance and home ownership assistance which the Government provides to all ADF members. A range of cash subsidy options was considered; from the simple cashing out of current rental subsidies, which would permit all ADF members to exercise choice in the selection of their accommodation, to an option which would allow members to use a cash subsidy either to rent or to buy a dwelling. The consultancy involved much broader issues than the capitalising of existing rental subsidies for use as a deposit on an owner-occupied home.
(iii) See answer to (1) (c) above.

(2) (a) occasional care centres are funded through the Family Support Funding Program each year. The Family Support Funding Program aims to enhance the lives of Defence families and improve the sense of community by providing grants for community projects developed by Defence families, encouraging Defence families and groups to determine needs in a local area, and increasing opportunities for Defence families to undertake self-help projects. Funding is based on submissions from the families themselves and may include centres, baby-sitting groups and playgroups depending on how families perceive their needs. The essential criteria of the program is that projects developed under the scheme must benefit a significant number of Defence families. The Government considers that the element of choice in the Family Support Funding Program is central to the success of the program, and the breakdown of activities on which monies are spent reflects the needs and priorities of local Defence families.

Since 1989-90, grants have been made to over 1,000 family groups, including child care grants totalling $468,722, grants for playgroups totalling $239,270, grants for playgrounds and recreational facilities totalling approximately $650,000 and grants for neighbourhood houses and community centres amounting to approximately $800,000.

It has been found that playgroups are required as much as occasional care as they are a good way of getting mothers and children together. Defence child care centres funded under the Defence employer-sponsored child care program for work-related child care also provide places for emergency respite care and some occasional care places.
(b) Occasional care was not specifically investigated as part of the Family Support Review. The Review examined structures within HQADF and the single Services for the delivery of family support.

(c) The Family Support Review has been completed and the implementation phase commenced on 13 February 1995. The need for Defence occasional care is being continuously addressed through the Family Support Funding Program. This program is based on submissions put forward by the families through the single Services.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice on, 13 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the fact that there is currently an anomaly in the taxation system in relation to sales tax on the components of a solar hot water system, including tanks and valves, such that some components are currently tax exempt whilst others attract a sales tax:
(1) Does the Minister consider that this is an anomaly that needs to be redressed to encourage householders and commercial enterprises to shift to this renewable water heating technology.
(2) Is the Government considering redressing this anomaly; if not, why not.
(3) Is the removal of sales tax on all renewable energy technology being considered; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government does not consider that current sales tax treatment of certain water holding tanks and valves is anomalous.

(2) As noted above, the Government does not consider the taxation of certain water holding tanks and valves to be anomalous. Indeed, to exempt water holding tanks from sales tax solely on the basis of whether they are attached to solar heating mechanisms would create anomalies. For example, no similar exemption would apply to other appliances that are powered by solar power.
The response to Senate question 1909 sets out further reasons why the Government does not propose to extend sales tax exemptions to water holding tanks attached to solar panels.

(3) The Government already provides sales tax exemptions on a range of solar energy equipment. Other products incorporating renewable energy technology—such as wind power and wave power—would often be exempt from sales tax under the business input exemption provisions of the sales tax legislation. Furthermore, research and development relating to renewable energy technology benefits from the generous tax concessions for research and development.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that: (a) solar hot water systems are currently tax exempt; and (b) one component, the water holding tank, and in some cases the valves of the solar hot water systems, is taxed as if it were a separate unit.
(2) Is this an anomaly.
(3) Should this be addressed in the interests of providing incentives and promoting the use of renewable energy and energy efficiency.

(4) In the light of the national greenhouse strategy, the aim of which is to reduce greenhouse emissions, would it be appropriate to provide as many incentives as possible for increasing the use of renewable sources.
(5) If this tax were removed, would it increase consumer demand and/or competitiveness for solar hot water.
(6) Does hot water account for the single biggest domestic consumption of energy.
(7) Will increased use of solar hot water assist in reducing our reliance on non-renewables.
(8) How much revenue is gained from tax on tanks used specifically for solar hot water.

(9) Is it intended that water holding tanks and valves bought for use with solar panels be dealt with as whole solar units, and therefore be completely tax free in order to give incentives for increasing solar use.
(10) What strategy does the Government have to increase the use of solar hot water systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The sales tax legislation provides exemptions for:
(a) goods of a kind ordinarily used for collecting, absorbing or concentrating the sun's rays for the purpose of using them as a source of heat;
(b) photovoltaic cells; and
(c) goods for use by a person mainly in facilitating the operation of goods covered by (a) and (b) above.
The sales tax legislation does not provide exemptions for water holding tanks or valves, regardless of the power source for heating water contained in the tank.
(3) There are several important arguments against exempting certain water holding tanks and valves from sales tax.

It is desirable that environmental objectives be pursued through measures which meet well defined environmental objectives in the most efficient way. Tanks designed for the storage of water, for whatever purpose, appear to have little or no environmental merit in themselves; extending taxation concessions to the water holding tanks of solar hot water systems would therefore result in an inefficient targeting of environmental objectives.

To exempt water holding tanks from sales tax solely on the basis of whether they are attached to solar heating mechanisms would create anomalies. For example, no similar exemption would apply to other appliances that are powered by solar power. Another anomaly could arise if those who purchase solar heating panels and attach them to their existing hot water tank were to pay a higher amount of sales tax relative to those who purchase the solar hot water system inclusive of the water tank.
The cost to the budget in the context of the Government's outlays, and tax expenditures, priorities is also a relevant consideration.

(4) No. Incentives need to be examined in the light of their cost and effectiveness in meeting their objectives. Some incentives will be better targeted and more efficient than others, while poorly targeted incentives should not be implemented.

(5) To the extent that there was a reduction in the price of solar hot water vis-a-vis water heated by other means, there could be some increase in demand for solar hot water systems. However, as the impact upon the price of the entire system would be relatively small, it is likely that the impact on demand would also be relatively small.
(6)—(7) I have referred these questions to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy for his reply.

(8) An estimate of this has not been compiled by the Australian Taxation Office or Treasury and I do not propose to authorise the expenditure of resources and effort that would be involved in compiling an estimate.
(10) I have referred this question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy for his reply.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 1 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to home equity conversion loans and the Advance Bank:
(1) What amount of Government funds was allocated in 1993-94 for home equity conversion (HEC) loans.
