(3) What is the length of the Advance Bank's tender.
(4) How many tenders were received by the department.
(5) What was the amount of the Advance Bank's tender.
(6) What is the rate of interest charged on a consumer's loan.
(7) What is the subsidy on the current variable interest rate on an HEC loan.
(8) How many loans have been made to date.
(9) What is the average amount of an approved HEC loan.
(10) Please provide details of departmental subsidies to the consumer in relation to establishment fees, interest rates and legal advice sought.
(11) What existing consumer legislation offers protection to HEC consumers.

(12) How are loan applicants made aware that their loan liability may increase significantly over time, that is, by the compounding of capital and interest and the consequences of interest rate rises and falling property values.
(13) What assessments have been made concerning the success of the scheme.
(14) What impact will the Government's efforts have on the number of households able to stay in their homes through having access to the HEC loan scheme.
(15) Is an increase expected in the number of finance vendors with reverse equity products.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The total Budget allocation for the three year term of the current agreement with the Advance Bank was $30 million. This was on a pro-rata basis of $10 million for each financial year of operation of the scheme.
(2) See answer to part (1).
(3) The term of the current agreement with the Advance Bank is for three years. The scheme commenced operation on 1 December 1993.
(4) I am not prepared to release the information as it impinges on commercial dealings with other parties and also on the business interests of the Commonwealth.

(5) The tender is not for a fixed total amount, being in the nature of direct subsidies to the Bank for promotion of the scheme, and subsidies in respect of each loan application received by the Bank.
(6) The interest rate payable by a borrower under the HEC scheme is the base variable owner/occupier home mortgage rate charged by the Bank, currently 9.5 per cent.

(7) The Commonwealth is subsidising the Bank so that the interest charged on the loan will equal the base variable owner/occupier home mortgage rate charged by the Bank from time to time. Without this subsidy, pensioners would have to pay a higher rate under the bank's normal risk criteria.
(8) To 2 March 1995, 3,048 loans have been approved by the Bank.

(9) The amount which can be borrowed under the HEC scheme is a maximum of $7,500 for pensioners aged 75 and over and $5,000 for other eligible pensioners. The minimum loan amount is $3,000. The average amount of all loans approved to 5 December 1994 is $5,324.
(10) The Commonwealth provides the following subsidies to the Bank:
an application fee subsidy so that a pensioner will have to pay only $30 of the application fee;
the cost of independent financial advice, to a maximum of $150, from a solicitor, a registered accountant or licensed financial planner;
an amount of up to $100 towards the cost of registration or stamp duty for any couple seeking to change a title deed by adding the name of one partner in order to access a loan; and
an interest subsidy (see answer to part (7)).
(11) The Trade Practices Act 1974 may provide substantial protection to HEC consumers who are victims of unconscionable conduct or misleading and deceptive conduct.

HEC loans which are deemed to be unconscionable (according to the unwritten law of the States and Territories) are prohibited under section 51AA of the Act, allowing access to a range of remedies available under sections 80 and 87. These could include injunctions or other remedial orders such as compensatory damages or variation of the loan contract.

Consumers may also be protected under section 52 of the Act, which prohibits misleading or deceptive conduct by a corporation in trade or commerce. HEC loan consumers who are subject to such misleading or deceptive conduct by the lending institution may be granted relief under sections 80 and 87, and may also take actions for damages under section 82.
Consumers claiming relief under the Trade Practices Act must commence their actions within certain time periods to ensure their rights are not statute barred.
The States and Territories also have responsibility for the regulation of such loan transactions under various pieces of State and Territory consumer protection legislation.

(12) It is a requirement of the scheme that all applicants for a loan obtain independent advice about the effects of making an application under the scheme and entering into a HEC loan. The cost of this advice is subsidised by the Commonwealth (see answer to part (10)).

(13) The Advance Bank is required to provide regular reports to the Department of Social Security, giving details of, among other things, enquiries, applications received, number and value of loans approved, number of loans rejected, and the number of complaints or disputes.
The Department's assessment of these reports is that the scheme is meeting the Government's objectives.

(14) The objective of the scheme is to enhance the quality of life of pensioners by giving greater access to the equity they have in their homes. There is no formal restriction on the use of a HEC loan and the purpose for which loans are used is not known.
(15) There is no evidence of an increase in the number of vendors offering reverse equity products since the scheme commenced.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that the use of RAAF Curtin as a detention centre for illegal immigrants is not consistent with the planned uses of the base when that facility was constructed; if not, why not.
(2) (a) If the base is required for military operations at short notice, how will this be possible given the presence on the base of perhaps hundreds of illegal immigrants; and
(b) will the presence of these detainees impact on the base's operational readiness; if not, why not.
(3) If the base is operationally impaired by the presence of immigration detainees, how can the Government guarantee the security of northern Australia.
(4) (a) How will the logistics of the `temporary' detention centre be handled given that the base is 50 kilometres from Derby; and
(b) what costs will be involved in getting supplies into the base for possibly hundreds of people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) (a) Should a situation arise where illegal immigrants are temporarily accommodated at RAAF Curtin, the airfield will still be available for essential Defence operations and steps have been taken to ensure that the security of the base is not compromised by the presence of non-Defence personnel on the base.
Furthermore, all activities, such as short-term programmed exercises, for RAAF Curtin during 1995 and early 1996 have been transferred to RAAF Learmonth.

(b) RAAF Curtin was designed as a `bare base', to be activated in a reasonable time-frame if our strategic environment deteriorates, or we otherwise foresee an impending operational requirement. As such, the base is not intended to maintain a high degree of operational readiness. However, should a situation arise where illegal immigrants were accommodated at RAAF Curtin coincident with a requirement to fully activate the base, the detainees would have to be relocated. The operational readiness of the base would not be affected unless the detainees were not relocated before the base was activated. This situation is assessed as highly unlikely.

(3) We do not predicate our strategy for the defence of northern Australia upon activation of RAAF Curtin at short notice, given our current strategic circumstances. We expect our intelligence and surveillance resources to provide adequate warning of any emerging threat to Australia, and we do not perceive any such threats in the short to medium term. Thus, a requirement to activate RAAF Curtin at short notice is highly unlikely. In these circumstances, the use of RAAF Curtin for temporary accommodation of immigration detainees will in no way adversely affect Australia's security.
Furthermore, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is well advanced in developing a more appropriate solution for the processing and accommodation of illegal immigrants.
I have received the following answer from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs for part 4 of the question.

(4) (a) Persons who arrive in Australia without authority and who are to be accommodated at the Curtin Defence base will be moved directly to the site via the base's airport. My Department will ensure that efforts are made to use local sources of supply of goods and services—especially from the nearby township of Derby, and arrangements will be put in place for catering, cleaning, medical and other services to be provided at the site by contractors.
(b) The actual cost of provision of these services has not yet been finally established since there has been no requirement to date to use the base as a place of detention.

(1) Did the source selection process leading to the selection of the S70 Blackhawk helicopters include calculations of the annual and through-life support costs based on data supplied by the tendering companies; if so, (a) what was the estimated annual and through-life cost of operating the Black Hawks, based on the Sikorsky data including: (i) frequency and cost of maintenance cycles; (ii) nature and cost of spare parts requirements; and (iii) frequency and cost of airframe inspections for corrosion and fatigue; and (b) were guarantees regarding the estimated and life-cycle operating costs required from Sikorsky as part of the contractual arrangements; if not, (c) on what basis was the impact of Blackhawks' operations on the Australian Defence Force's recurrent costs estimated; and (d) what data sources were available to assess future impact of Blackhawk operations on the Army's running cost base.

(2) (a) What variation has occurred from the estimated frequency and cost of maintenance of the Blackhawk Helicopters; (b) when was this variation discovered; (c) what is the impact of this variation: (i) in terms of annual and through-life costs, (ii) in terms of the helicopters operational performance envelope, and (iii) in terms of the helicopters future operational availability.

(3) (a) At what dates were the Blackhawk helicopters (which were unserviceable at Townsville on 25 January) declared unserviceable; (b) what was the cause of each being unserviceable; (c) in each case was each defect discovered during prescribed inspection routines or as the result of a flight incident report; and (d) in each case, how long is estimated that the defect had been in existence before discovery.

(4) (a) When was it decided to use long-range fuel tanks on the Blackhawk helicopters; (b) was operation of the Blackhawk with long-range fuel tanks an operational requirement evaluated by the project team during the source selection process; and (c) were the tanks acquired at the time the helicopters were procured.
(5) Did the department advise the Government about the need for long-range fuel tanks; if so, when; if it did not provide this advice, why not.

(6) Did the department provide Sikorsky with a full briefing of the intended uses of the Australian Blackhawks, in particular, did the department inform Sikorsky that it was likely that the Australian Blackhawk helicopters would be equipped with long-range fuel tanks on a frequent basis; if not, why not.

(7) If the department did consult Sikorsky on the intended use of the Blackhawks including the use of the long-range fuel tanks on a frequent basis, did the department seek from Sikorsky a forward assessment of the effects that these tanks would have on the performance, the air frame and life-of-type (that is lifespan) of the Blackhawks; if so, what was Sikorsky's response; if not, why not.

(8) If the department did not provide Sikorsky with an outline of the intended uses, did the department accept performance and life-of-type data based upon United States operating requirements and experience.

(9) If the department was aware that the use of long-range fuel tanks would compromise the integrity of the Blackhawk airframe, did it fail to warn the Government that the tanks would cause costly damage to the airframe of the helicopters.

(10) Given that the Government has decided to allocate additional funds for the procurement of Blackhawk spare parts, will these funds come from: (a) existing projected Army operating costs: if so, from which areas and what are the totals from each area; and (b) from unprogrammed increases in the defence budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) (i) The original Blackhawk maintenance cycle included four routine services; R1, R2, R3 and R4 which were to be conducted every 10, 25, 100 and 400 hours respectively.
Through life costs assessments were conducted during the source selection process and showed that routine servicing required approximately 5,500 maintenance manhours per 1,000 flying hours.

(ii) $75.9 million was allocated for spares for the first three years of operation. This is consistent with the normal expectation that initial spares would be approximately 15% of the cost of the prime equipment.
(iii) Inspections for corrosion and cracking are included in the major routine services ie R2 and R3 and previously R4.

(b) The figures provided by Sikorsky for life-cycle costings were estimates and depend to a large degree on the operational usage of the aircraft and the particular environment in which it operates. It is not possible to obtain contractual guarantees on operating costs for military aircraft as the customer's variations in operational requirements are beyond the contractor's control.

(c) The impact of Blackhawk operations on recurrent cost estimates was calculated against a baseline annual usage rate of 7,370 hours. Planning allowed the annual usage rate to rise in increments to a mature rate of 9,300 hours in financial year 1994/95.

(d) Initially, the main sources of information were Sikorsky and the US Armed Forces. These have since been supplemented by data gained from a survey of Australian use of the Blackhawk. Maintenance and spares requirements are continually updated as changes are made in the achieved and anticipated usage of the fleet, particularly the number of hours flown annually.
(2) (a-b) The following table shows the original and current frequency of the maintenance cycle.

The content of maintenance schedules continually evolves as new requirements become evident, and old requirements change or become redundant. The maintenance cycle is structured to obtain the most efficient use of time that an aircraft spends in maintenance, and to ensure that the availability of deployed aircraft for operational task is maximised.

The manpower required for the current schedule is approximately 4,870 maintenance manhours per 1,000 flying hours and represents a 10% reduction from the original schedule. This does not include the requirement for special repairs, such as corrosion and cracking.

The current maintenance schedule was introduced in 1992, and last amended in November 1994. The frequency of routine maintenance has been reduced. However, the time spent by aircraft off-line has increased. The last formal maintenance study conducted was based upon 1993 figures. Since then, overall maintenance manhours have increased as a result of:
A corrosion control program is in place requ iring the more frequent washing and inspection s (every 14 days). Corrosion repair has increas ed, and is generally conducted every 500 hours .
Blackhawks are now subjected to vibration analysis every 100 hours. This allows the rotor systems to be adjusted to minimise the vibratio ns, reducing airframe fatigue.
Reduced component retirement times causin g more frequent replacement of some flight critical components.

As R1 and R2 servicings are performed in-house it is not possible to identify the discreet costs for these routine services. However, R3 servicing is carried out under contract to Aerospace Technologies of Australia Ltd and, on average, there are 13 services carried out each year at an average cost of approximately $58,000, including corrosion repair.

(c) (i) A review is currently being conducted to examine past funding levels, and use this data to forecast future funding requirements. It is probable overall costs will increase over the current Five Year Defence Program due to the need to return spares holdings to acceptable levels, effect the repair of repairable parts, and overcome the corrosion and cracking problems.

(ii) It is too early to determine if there will be any continuing effect on the performance envelope, particularly until the cracking problem is resolved. It is unlikely that the performance envelope itself will change although the frequency that some manoeuvres are conducted within that envelope may be reduced. Army has already restricted some manoeuvres and use of the External Stores Support System (ESSS) until more data is available.

(iii) The shortage of spares, combined with the long procurement lead times for some spares, will not permit Army to substantially recover from the current low aircraft availability until at least late 1995.
(3) (a-c) The aircraft were declared unserviceable between 26 September 1994 and 25 January 1995. Specific details will be provided separately to Senator Newman.
(d) Any answer would be speculative.

(4) (a) The Request for Tender (RFT) for the supply of Utility Helicopters for the RAAF included a requirement that the aircraft should have a ferry range of 1100 kms, with a 30 minute reserve. There was no indication of the percentage of time that was to be spent in this role.

During the tender evaluation phase, it was assessed that the Blackhawk could adequately fulfil the role if fitted with External Stores Support Systems (ESSS) and four external fuel tanks. As such, three ESSS and 14 x 230 gallon fuel tanks were ordered under the initial Phase 1 of the Blackhawk procurement of 14 aircraft.

The RFT for Phase 2 of the Blackhawk acquisition was issued on 4 December 1986. This RFT required that the helicopter must be capable of self deployment to anywhere in Australia. It was determined that this capability was best provided by ESSS with four 230 gallon fuel tanks. 25 ESSS and 100 fuel tanks were ordered in Phase 2.
(b) Yes.

(c) 14 x 230 gallon fuel tanks were procured under the Prime Contract. An additional 100 x 230 gallon were purchased directly from Sikorsky's sub-contractor at the same time. All ESSSs and fuel tanks were delivered during February-May 1989.

(5) The Government was formally advised of the requirement to acquire the ESSS with fuel tanks as part of the Cabinet Submission seeking project approval for the acquisition of 39 Blackhawk helicopters. That approval was given on 8 May 1987.

(6) Sikorsky was briefed, in general terms, on the ADF's proposed usage. Sikorsky's technical specification assumed use of the full external tank ferry configuration for 3% of the aircraft's life. The ADF's operational requirements exceed US Army experience. An US Army report on ESSS configuration was supplied through Sikorsky in late 1987. The impact of Australian ESSS usage is being addressed by ongoing studies by Sikorsky and the ADF.

(7) In addition to the US Army material provided in 1987, Sikorsky suggested that, in view of the likely ADF usage of the Blackhawk, studies and ongoing assessment of the use of the ESSS was required to validate, amongst other things, data on component replacement times.
(8) Initially, US Army information on performance and life-of-type data was used.

(9) The current problem concerning the stress on parts of the airframe as the result of use of the ESSS was not foreseen. When it was ascertained that use of the ESSS need to be modified, appropriate action was taken by Army. A program to correct the present cracking problem is being developed.

(10) (a-b) Initial funding of $8 million for Blackhawk spares has been provided from Army's allocation. The funds were available due to an underspend in the personnel area. In addition, $13 million has been committed for financial year 1995/96 and beyond. A comprehensive review of funding requirements over the Five Year Defence Program is currently under way. The source of the additional funds has yet to be determined but will be met from within existing Defence Outlays.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 8 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Omega Station in Gippsland and comments by Mr Paul Molloy of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that Omega was to close on 28 February 1994, and statements made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Gareth Evans on 7 September 1993 which gave the United States 180 days notice to close Omega:

(1)(a) Is the Omega transmitter to be shut down, given the above comments and the latest radio spectrum frequency report which outlines the band Omega transmits on is still active and not under review; if so, when; if not, why not; and (b) please explain the comments of the Minister and Mr Molloy.
(2)(a) What is the intended future use of the Omega transmitter; and (b) what is Australia's future role in the Omega system.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) An interim decision to give notice of the closure of the Omega station on 28 February 1994, announced in the statement issued jointly by the Minister for Transport and Communications and myself on 7 September 1993, was subsequently withdrawn after consultation with affected parties revealed considerable demand for the station's services.
The following sets out the background to these decisions.

The Australian Omega station in Gippsland is run by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. Upon its establishment in 1982 the costs of the station's operation were met by the commercial shipping industry. This was in accordance with the anticipated use by commercial shipping in the Australian region of the Omega system for navigation. By 1993, however, it was clear that the Omega system served no useful purpose for marine navigation in the Australian region. The industry was thus no longer willing to continue funding the station's operation.

In the absence of alternative funding arrangements an interim decision was made by the Government that the station would close. In accordance with the original bilateral agreement between Australia and the United States under which the station operated within the world-wide Omega system, the Australian Government gave the US Government 180 days notice of the intended closure. This was reflected in the joint statement made on 7 September 1993 by Senator Collins, as Minister for Transport and Communications, and myself. That statement did, however, also make clear that the Department of Transport and Communications and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade would, prior to the Government's final decision on the station's future, seek submissions from affected users to assist the Government in making that decision.

In the course of this consultative process, there arose a number of appeals for the station's continued operation, including from other countries and from the World Meteorological Organisation. It became clear that the Omega system was still used for sea and air navigation in a number of other countries, as well as for the gathering of essential meteorological information by the Australian Bureau of Meteorology, and by other meteorological bodies throughout the Asia-Pacific region, particularly in the South Pacific, and in southern Africa. As a result, the Government decided to itself provide funding for the continued operation of the station, until 30 September 1997; that funding being provided through the Australian Bureau of Meteorology. A media release on this matter was issued by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority on 1 June 1994.

(b) This final decision was therefore a reflection of the Government's stated intention, referred to in the joint statement of Senator Collins and myself on 7 September 1993, to take into account the views of affected users. Mr Molloy's statement regarding the station's closure was made prior to the Government's final decision, and reflected the initial interim decision for the station to close upon the expiry of the 180 day period of notice given to the United States Government.

(2)(a) As set out in the reply to (1)(a) above, the signals from the Australian Omega station's transmitter are used for navigation in a number of countries (although such usage will continue to decline in favour of more accurate systems, particularly satellite navigation), and for the gathering of essential meteorological information (through the tracking of weather balloons) by the Australian Bureau of Meteorology, and by other meteorological bodies throughout the Asia-Pacific region and in southern Africa.

(b) The continued operation of the Australian Omega station until 30 September 1997 and its role within the world-wide Omega system is to be confirmed in an exchange of notes, which will constitute an agreement between Australia and the US. The draft notes, which are currently before Executive Council specify that, "The Omega signals from the Facility shall be used only for navigation, for search and rescue operations, for time dissemination, for climate monitoring and other meteorological purposes and for other purposes as mutually determined by the Parties, but shall not be used for communications other than those necessary to ensure the integrated operations of the Facility as part of the world-wide Omega System." The draft notes further specify that, "In order to provide for certainty, especially for users and for employees of the Facility, both Parties shall endeavour to reach a mutual understanding at the earliest possible date as to whether, and under what conditions, the Facility will be operated beyond 30 September 1997."

(5) Assuming these agencies are staffed under the Public Service Act: (a) do the chief executive officers of these agencies have the power to create senior executive service positions under the Public Service Act; (b) in the event that these agencies create new SES positions in excess of their agreed profile cover, is approval required from the department for the creation of the additional SES positions for both short term (say up to 12 months) and long term positions; (c) does the department allocate `running costs' or `SES notional budgets' to these two agencies to control SES salaries expenditure; and (d) if no Department of Finance approval is required for the creation of short or long term SES positions, what controls are there on management in these agencies to prevent them creating several new short or long term SES positions and thereby enriching their SES salary profiles and expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to media reports concerning the delayed departure from Townsville of the second Australian Defence Force (ADF) contingent to Rwanda on the weekend of 18 and 19 February 1995.
(1) What was the cause of the delayed departure of the Boeing 747 aircraft chartered by the United Nations (UN).

(2) (a) How were the faults with the aircraft discovered; (b) by whom; (c) when; and (d) what action was required before the aircraft was cleared for takeoff from Townsville by the Civil Aviation Authority.

(3) (a) What action has been taken in response to the grounding of the aircraft; and (b) what assurances have been sought from the UN about the safety and reliability of the aircraft used to transport peacekeeping contingents from member states.
(4) (a) Who is the owner and operator of the aircraft; and (b) under what conditions was the aircraft chartered to the UN.
(5) What is the rationale for using UN-chartered aircraft to transport the ADF contingent to Rwanda.

(6) What consideration has been given to offering Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) or Qantas aircraft for charter to the UN for the purposes of transporting this, or previous, Australian peacekeeping contingents; if no such consideration has been given, why not.
(7) Has the Government considered using RAAF or Qantas aircraft to transport personnel to Rwanda, rather than using UN-chartered aircraft; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The delayed departure of the Boeing 747 aircraft was directly attributable to the need to rectify a number of faults before the aircraft was cleared for takeoff by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). The faults which were listed in the aircraft log and/or identified by CAA staff included: an engine oil leak, a defective wheel flap door microswitch, low electrical power in the auxiliary power unit batteries, damage to door seals, and the need for a temporary repair to a wing root panel to be more permanently repaired.

(2) (a) to (c) A RAAF Flying Safety Officer detected an engine oil leak and called in a CAA airworthiness inspector who inspected both the aircraft and its log. The aircraft's captain had noted a number of faults in the log during the inbound flight and the CAA inspection of the aircraft detected some additional faults.
(d) The faults had to be repaired to the satisfaction of the CAA before the aircraft was cleared for takeoff.

(3) (a) The ADF took immediate action to notify the UN in New York, through the Australian Mission to the UN, of the problems encountered, and to express Australian concerns that the UN-chartered aircraft failed to meet CAA standards, thereby potentially endangering the welfare of Australian military personnel.

(b) The UN's Field Administration and Logistics Division has responded expressing sincere regrets and apologies over the incident, assuring the ADF that the UN will insist that all aviation service contractors comply with its aviation safety policy and International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) standards. The UN has also conveyed our concerns to Tower Air management, and reiterated UN requirements that safety be the overriding factor in the carriage of personnel from contributing member states.
(4) (a) The aircraft is owned and operated by the United States carrier Tower Air which is on the US Federal Register.

(b)The aircraft was chartered by the UN following normal tender processes. The successful airline is required to meet International Air Transport Association regulations which contain the same safety standards as the ICAO.

(5), (6) and (7) The UN is responsible for arranging and funding transport resources to move participating contingents to UN areas of operation. In the case of the deployment of the first ADF contingent to Rwanda in August last year, the UN arranged for the uplift of an advance party comprising 73 personnel, plus additional equipment and stores, using one US Air Force (USAF) C5 Galaxy aircraft. The main body, comprising 220 personnel, equipment and stores was uplifted by nine USAF C5 Galaxy and one C141 Starlifter aircraft and three commercially chartered B747 freighters. The UN Letter of Assist issued to the US to cover the cost of the ADF deployment to Rwanda was valued at US$8.6 million at no cost to Australia. A similar airlift by the RAAF would have involved in excess of 80 C130 aircraft flights. The RAAF simply did not possess the capacity to undertake such a significant task in the necessary timeframe.

Should the priority of movement so dictate and RAAF assets prove suitable for the task at an acceptable cost, the use of ADF resources is actively considered. However, the UN has advised that costs will only be reimbursed to the level that would have been incurred had the UN arranged the charter. RAAF capacity is limited when compared with more cost effective aircraft, such as civil 747 aircraft chartered by the UN.

Any Qantas bid to provide air transport in support of UN operations is a commercial decision made by Qantas management. Were Qantas to bid for UN work, it would do so in competition with other international service providers. For instance, Qantas was unsuccessful for the Rwanda withdrawal but were used in the initial ADF deployment into Somalia and redeployment.

The recent Commonwealth Government Budget announced a two year New Homes for Old (NHFO) Initiative. The initiative draws on work undertaken by the Australian Urban and Regional Development Review.

New Homes for Old aims to increase older people's awareness of and access to a diversity of housing options and to improve industry and government responses to providing housing for the increasing numbers of older Australians.
Outcomes expected for older people would be:
easier access to funding and more responsive financing arrangements for housing,
access to appropriate housing diversity in all neighbourhoods across urban areas,
readily accessible, locally relevant information on housing choices.

The `New Homes for Old Strategy' paper prepared by the Australian Urban and Regional Development Review (attached), found that the housing options available for the increasingly large numbers of older Australians are inadequate because of limited variety of housing types in most communities. The paper concludes urgent action is required as significant change to available housing stock involves substantial time lags.

The overall objective of the study is to examine the feasibility of, and extent of interest in, private sector investment in an instrument to provide finance to facilitate both the supply and demand for private housing for people aged 55 years and over. It is believed that older people do not currently have the financing options available to them with which to maximise their housing choices and options.
It is the belief of the Department that to arrive at any meaningful discussion on possible financial instruments, a preliminary analysis of the issue of market failure in this area will be necessary.
This study will examine the financing issues, including any market failure and the role financial institutions are playing (or could play) in this area.

examination of the feasibility of setting up an investment infrastructure to facilitate greater housing choice for older people (a related aim is to advance integrated urban, housing and social planning—while this study should keep this issue in mind it is not central to this investigation);

consideration of the current or potential role of the various financial institutions, private sector producers, property managers in all sectors, churches, voluntary organisations and local government, and identifying the kinds of products to be financed; and
development of options for the appropriate role, if any, for the Commonwealth.
The consultant will identify, document and make recommendations in addressing the following—
review of related studies;
examination of any current market failure;
the structure and operation of existing or possible financial instruments or mechanisms that are both viable and sustainable;
the types of investors who may be interested;
rate of return expected/required;
perceived and real risk factors;
possible incentives needed to attract investors, including any tax treatments of various instruments or mechanisms under current taxation principles;
disincentives for investors including issues such as security of tenure; and
the role of government (including any potential costs to government) in achieving viability for any proposed financial instrument or mechanism.

It is the responsibility of the consultant to set out in the proposal a detailed outline of a methodology which will facilitate the successful completion of the project in a timely and effective manner.
The Department reserves the right to allocate priorities to tasks within the project throughout the contract.

The consultant will be responsible for the production of a report covering all aspects of the research. Graphic material including maps, diagrams and photographs should be included. Audio visual material to accompany the report would be acceptable but it is not essential.
The content of the report will encompass all of the material described under `Research Tasks' above.
The report will need to be in a format suited to a range of audiences including government, developers, planners, community organisations and the general public.
It is expected that the study will be completed within ten weeks of commencement.
The consultant will need to provide short written reports on work in progress and key developments fortnightly.
Consultants tendering to undertake this project should submit a research proposal in accordance with this brief but in addition clearly specifying the following:
(a) previous background and experience in management of relevant research

Proposals for this Consultancy will be evaluated by the following criteria:

The consultant will be engaged using the standard Commonwealth contract which requires the consultant to declare any conflict or risk of interest. Where the Department establishes, from information available to it, that a conflict of interest exists, such conflict may be grounds for excluding the consultant from consideration for this consultancy. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 1 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of proposals by the Gold Coast tourist attraction Sea World to import dolphins and whales to be kept in captivity in the marine park.
(2) Is it the case that a permit is required before such imports can be made.

(3) If a permit is required: (a) what is the legislative or legal basis upon which the power to issue the permit is based; (b) who is responsible for issuing the permits; and (c) what criteria are used in making the decision.
(4) Is it required that any application for a permit has to be made public before a decision on the issue of that permit has been made.
(5) For what other animals is a permit required before importation into Australia is permitted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, I am aware of a proposal by Sea World that they may wish to import dolphins at some time in the future. No approach has been made to import whales.
(2) Yes, under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 (the Act) a permit is required prior to the import of any dolphin or whale.
(3) (a) The legislative or legal basis which requires the prior granting of a permit before a dolphin or whale can be imported are controls contained within the Act.

(b) Either myself, as Minister with portfolio responsibility for the Act, or the Designated Authority, which in this case is the Chief Executive Officer of the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, are responsible for issuing permits under the Act.

(c) The criteria used in making a decision varies significantly, depending on the type of application being made. In the case of dolphins or whales, because of Australia's strong stance on how we treat these species, an application under the Act seeking to import these species is only considered in the following specific circumstances:
Firstly, the applicant must be able to establish that exceptional circumstances exist and secondly, the applicant must satisfy one of the following categories:
that it will be a zoological exchange; or
that it will be for prescribed scientific research; or
that the animal has been bred in captivity.

(4) No, there is no requirement under the Act for every application for a permit to be made public before a permit is issued. Although not a legislative requirement, in the case of any applications to import dolphins to Sea World, I will advise the public of the proposal and seek their opinion.

(5) Under the Act, a permit is required to import any live animal, except for those species listed on Schedules 5 or 6 to the Act. Schedule 5 includes domestic species such as dogs, sheep and poultry, which are controlled by legislation administered by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Schedule 6 mainly includes marine and fresh water aquarium fish.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the announcement in 1991 by former Prime Minister Hawke that the Government would phase out the export of woodchips by the year 2000:

(1) Did the Prime Minister state on 22 December 1994 that the export of woodchips could be permitted after the year 2000 under regional forest agreements; if so, does this mean that the earlier Hawke commitment has been overridden.
(2) What is the status of `in principle licences' approved beyond the year 2000.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Woodchips exported from native forests will be reduced by 20 per cent each year over the next five years except for areas where there has been significant progress towards, or the completion of, a regional forest agreement (RFA) that provides for the establishment of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system, as required under the National Forest Policy Statement (NFPS). This phase-out will not apply to plantations. This means that for 1996, the maximum permissable level for export will be 4.8 million tonnes, for 1997 it will be 3.6 million tonnes, 1998 2.4 million tonnes, 1999 1.2 million tonnes to nil in 2000.

The consequence of this strategy is that from the year 2000, hardwood woodchip exports will only be approved for areas covered by, or where significant progress has been made towards, a regional forest agreement, and from plantations.

The Government's strategy is not inconsistent with the approach outlined by the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in 1991. Mr Hawke stated that the Government's objective would be to phase out woodchip exports from native forests in favour of an increase in downstream processing by the year 2000. However, Mr Hawke also stated that woodchips exports would be considered on a case-by-case basis, after the year 2000, with full regard being paid to the objective that the fullest possible return be achieved from Australia's forest resources. The Prime Minister has simply placed Mr Hawke's statement into the context of the NFPS, which has been signed since the former Prime Minister's 1991 statement.

(2) Three export woodchip licence holders have been given in-principle approval to export woodchips beyond the year 2000. In each of these cases the approval has been expressed to be subject to the issue of annual export licences. The intention of the Commonwealth in granting in-principle approval is to provide woodchip export companies with some degree of assurance and to justify commitments of capital. It is also intended to address the importance of security of supply for purchasers and requirements of charter arrangements for shipping.

The Government believes that RFAs are the key to meeting conservation objectives and giving security to woodchip export licence holders. These agreements will identify areas available for logging and those requiring protection through a comprehensive, adequate and representative CAR reserve system. Once RFAs are in place, it is intended that companies will be issued with licences for periods substantially longer than the current one year period.

(2) Select studies by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, which is funded through an initiative of the Commonwealth government using funds from the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, indicate that the prevalence of diabetes in Aboriginal populations exceeds 20%, almost four-times the rate in the non-Aboriginal population. Additional data seems to show that diabetes has become increasingly identified as a primary cause of death among Aboriginal males; the rate appears to have increased from 1 in 55 deaths to 1 in 35 deaths.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 6 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: The following advice has been received from the Federal Airports Corporation:

The new Brisbane International Terminal Complex is designed to grow in capacity by the addition of further aircraft positions and building modules as demand requires. Its initial capacity will be 1200 passengers per hour through eight aerobridges and three additional aircraft parking positions (a total of eleven parking positions). TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 6 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Who is responsible for the ABC "Country Hour" and where are they based.
(2) To what extent do State-based managers and presenters of the ABC "Country Hour" have control over their program and must they comply with national directives.

(3) (a) How many people are employed in Victoria to work on ABC "Country Hour" and what are their roles; and (b) how many people are employed in New South Wales to work on ABC "Country Hour" and what are their roles.

(4) Has any decision been made within the ABC to put greater emphasis on newer hobby-type operations at the expense of more traditional industry operations on ABC "Country Hour"; if so, please specify.
(5) Has any decision been made within the ABC to adopt a more confrontationist approach to interviewing on the ABC "Country Hour"; if so, please specify.
(6) What proportion of the content on the Victorian edition of ABC "Country Hour" emanates from Victoria.

(7) (a) What areas and what proportion of Victoria does not have ready access to ABC "Country Hour"; and (b) is it, or has it ever been, ABC policy that ABC "Country Hour" should be available to all Victorians.

(8) (a) To what extent has the move to the FM-band resulted in a loss of access to the ABC "Country Hour" in Victoria; (b) why has this loss occurred; and (c) do near metropolitan listeners have to install a special receiver at a cost of approximately $1,000 to have access to the ABC "Country Hour".

(9) (a) Why are the reports on the principal mutton sheep markets and computer aided livestock marketing (CALM) not included in the daily ABC "Country Hour" reports; and (b) will these reports be included in the future; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC):

PARA.TAB: (1) The "Country Hour" programs broadcast on Regional Radio around Australia are produced by the ABC Radio's Rural Department. This Department provides local, state and national rural programs including state based "Country Hour" programs.
Each "Country Hour" is a State-based program, with a ten minute national bulletin which must be included in all State editions.

Each State-based "Country Hour" has a full time presenter and a full time executive producer based in the capital city, plus a team of regionally based rural reporters filing material to the capital cities.

There are 28 regionally based rural reporters around Australia who produce a daily local morning program broadcast on Regional Radio in addition to contributing to the "Country Hour" and other state and national programs.
The ten minute national bulletin within the "Country Hour", is produced by a single reporter in Sydney, with contributions from reporters around Australia.

Each state Executive Producer (EP) is editorially responsible for rural programming produced within the state including that State's edition of the "Country Hour". They work to the National Rural Editor who is responsible for overseeing the editorial content of all state based programs, as well as the content of the ten minute national bulletin.
(2) The state presenters work editorially to the state EP, who works editorially to the National Rural Editor. The state based teams must comply with national directives.
(3)(a) The Victorian "Country Hour" has two full time capital city based staff, one Presenter and one EP who is responsible for the program's editorial output and the program's on-air production.

The EP is also responsible for three regionally based rural reporters who produce and present an early morning rural report broadcast on their local regional stations, as well as contributing to the "Country Hour" as required. These reporters are based in Horsham, Sale and Shepparton.
In addition, there are three staff located in Melbourne who produce and present Countrywide, the national daily rural issues program broadcast on Radio National.

(b) As with Victoria and other States, the New South Wales "Country Hour" has two full time capital city based staff, one presenter and one EP, who is responsible for the program's editorial output and the program's on-air production.

The EP is also responsible for the work and administration of eight regionally based rural reporters who produce and present an early morning rural report broadcast on their local regional station, as well as contributing to the "Country Hour" as required. These reporters are based in Bega, Dubbo, Kempsey, Lismore, Muswellbrook, Orange, Tamworth and Wagga Wagga.

(4) The task of Rural Reporters around Australia includes responding to trends in agriculture and the development of new industries. As a result of increased financial pressure on primary producers, there has been increased interest in the ability of farms to diversify into different enterprises which provide additional cash flow. These industries are reported on according to their importance, news value, interest and economic value.
This coverage has not been at the expense of the more traditional industry operations.
There has been no increase in recent years in coverage of "hobby type" operations.
(6) The Victorian "Country Hour" emanates from Victoria with the exception of the ten minute national bulletin from 12.06 to 12.16.

(7) (a)-(b) The "Country Hour" is broadcast on all ABC Regional Radio stations in Victoria. In recent years, sixteen additional transmitters to improve reception of Regional Radio have been installed by the National Transmission Agency (NTA) in regional Victoria as part of the Government's Second Regional Radio Network program.

The "Country Hour" is not broadcast to Melbourne and surrounding areas, such as Geelong, Warburton, Eildon, and Alexandra, which receive ABC Metropolitan Radio. The NTA is examining the possibility of establishing a transmission facility to serve the Alexandra area. If established, the ABC would propose to provide a Regional Radio program input for the transmission facility.

Prior to 1993, "Country Hour" was broadcast on Radio National in addition to Regional Radio, and was therefore available to the metropolitan and outer metropolitan audience. This was a national program with a twenty minute local window for state-based information.

Following a major review of the Rural Department's operations and programs completed in 1992, it was decided listeners would be better served by a fully State-based "Country Hour", and a specialist national rural issues program on Radio National. The Radio National program, Countrywide, is broadcast nationally from Melbourne between 1.30pm and 2.00pm daily.

(8) (a)-(c) There are pockets in the Great Dividing Range to the south-east of Albury that do not have access to the Victorian "Country Hour" program because ABC Radio decided to have the NTA AM transmitter at Corowa (2CO) broadcast the Riverina Regional programming including NSW "Country Hour". This has provided large areas of southern NSW, which previously received Victorian programming, with appropriate state-based informa tion.

These pockets exist because the coverage of the FM transmitter broadcasting on 106.5MHz from Mt Baranduda, which broadcasts the CO-FM Goulburn-Murray programming from the Albury studios, is different from the coverage of the Corowa AM transmitter. Regional Radio has not moved from the AM band in any other area of Victoria.

As mentioned above Regional Radio, and therefore "Country Hour", is not intended for broadcast to Melbourne and surrounding areas, including Geelong. Any reception in these centres, therefore, would be fortuitous.

(9) Livestock reports are broadcast on a daily basis in "Country Hour" reports. In Victoria, "Country Hour" broadcasts reports on the indicator markets as provided by the Department of Agriculture's Livestock Market Reporting service. These include:
Monday: Dandenong cattle; Bendigo mutton.
Tuesday: Dandenong cattle; Wodonga cattle; Ballarat lambs and mutton, usually devoting about three-quarters of the report to lambs.
Wednesday: Korumburra cattle; Warrnambool cattle.
Thursday: Wagga lambs.
Friday: Korumburra cattle; Shepparton lambs; and mutton markets on the Eastern States Market Summary.

The ABC broadcasts these daily reports because saleyard auction markets still account for a significant number of sheep, cattle and lamb sales. Daily markets are the most immediate indicator of livestock prices, with reports usually reaching "Country Hour" live from the saleyards as the sale is still under way. Livestock markets are reported because they are considered the only true and open indicator of when livestock values change on a daily basis. Most other indicators such as Computer Aided Livestock Markets (CALM) base their prices on daily livestock prices.

Daily livestock markets still account for over 50% of cattle, and about 30-40% of sheep and lambs sold in NSW (the remainder is a mixture of direct sales from paddock, `Over the Hooks' (animals that have been killed, dressed, weighed and assessed) and CALM).
Sheep and lamb markets are reported on NSW "Country Hour" with the key indicator markets used being Bendigo, Griffith, Wagga Wagga and Forbes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Kangaroo `95 defence exercises:

(1) For each of the countries participating in the exercises, namely Australia, the United Kingdom, United States of America, Malaysia, Singapore, Papua New Guinea and Indonesia, provide a breakdown of: (a) the numbers of total troops committed from each country; (b) the numbers of speciality troops committed from each country and their purpose; (c) the number and type of equipment (tanks, ships, aircraft) committed from each country; and (d) the role of each country in the exercises.

(2) Will Indonesian troops be participating in preliminary exercises in April 1995 in preparation for Kangaroo `95; if so, (a) How many troops will be arriving; (b) on what dates will they arrive and leave; (c) are the troops from a parachute platoon; (d) which platoon will troops be from and what activities will they take part in; (e) where in northern Australia will these troops be training or taking part in activities leading up to the full defence exercises in August 1995; (f) will any elite forces be arriving in April 1995; if so: (i) which ones; (ii) how many; and (iii) why will they be here; and (g) what is the purpose of troop visits in April to prepare for Kangaroo `95 exercise; and what preparations, if any, are needed.

(3) With reference to the report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 9 February 1995, `Joint exercise may lead to military arm': (a) Will 500 troops from Indonesia participate in Kangaroo `95, as claimed in the article; and (b) have exercise planners carefully designed the manoeuvres to virtually quarantine the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) troops from each other to avoid any unnecessary friction, as also reported in the article; (c) which ASEAN troop relations would potentially be a source of friction; (d) does the Government believe that by separating different countries' troops during the exercise this will in the long term reduce friction and get troops working together co-operatively; (e) would the reduction of friction be better served by a non-separation of troops forced to work together co-operatively for a common purpose; (f) in the context of a real invasion, would it be practical and effective for our neighbour's forces that come to our aid to be separate in the field; if not, what then is the purpose of the separation of ASEAN troops; (g) how will different nations' troops be separated and deployed in the field during the Kangaroo `95 exercises; and (h) in what broad regions will they be placed.

(4) Has New Zealand been banned from participating in the Kangaroo `95 defence exercises for its anti-nuclear and anti-alliance stance in relation to the United States; if so, why; (b) why does New Zealand bilateral relations with the United States influence our own defence strategy; and (c) how important is New Zealand to Australia's defence strategy in general and under the ANZUS treaty.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: 1(a) The anticipated numbers of Defence Force personnel participating in Exercise Kangaroo 95 are: Australia 15,750; United Kingdom 280; USA 1960; Indonesia 160; Malaysia 60; Singapore 60; and Papua New Guinea 20.
(b) All participating personnel are trained as specialists of one form or another. A full list of specialisations is not available.

(c) The full range of Australian defence equipment relevant to short-warning conflict will be employed or simulated during the exercise. The major elements contributed by other participating nations is expected to be: United Kingdom—1 frigate, 1 support tanker; USA—1 landing ship, 2 frigates, 1 submarine, 2 maritime patrol aircraft; Indonesia—2 transport aircraft; Malaysia—headquarters elements; Singapore—headquarters elements; and Papua New Guinea—1 patrol boat.
(d) The role of the participants will be to join with the Australian Defence Force in conducting conventional defence exercises in northern Australia and its maritime approaches.

2(a-g) As publicly announced at the time, Indonesian forces participated with the Australian Army in Exercise Swift Canopy on 6-13 March 1995. This was a conventional warfare exercise involving Army parachute and ground operations at Shoalwater Bay Training Area in Queensland, which served as a lead-up training exercise for Indonesian participation in Exercise Kangaroo 95. Forty-six Indonesian personnel, consisting of a platoon of airborne troops from the Strategic Reserve Command (KOSTRAD) and military observers, and an Indonesian Air Force C-130 aircraft and crew participated in the exercise. The exercise allowed the forces from both countries the opportunity to practice military skills and to foster an understanding of each other's military practices and procedures.
3(a) No. Approximately 160 Indonesian troops will be involved in Kangaroo 95.

(b-g) Contrary to the erroneous press report cited in the question, Exercise Kangaroo 95 does not envisage the establishment of any regional military alliance. Regional involvement in Kangaroo 95 has been designed instead to provide neighbouring countries' forces with bilateral exercise opportunities with the Australian Defence Force. Regional participation in exercises in Australia is an important dimension of our increasing engagement with countries of Asia and the Pacific. At the same time, our highest defence priority is to maintain forces which are capable of defending Australia without combat support from other countries.

(h) In order to obtain greatest value from the exercise, details of areas of operations within the exercise area will remain closely guarded by exercise planners—including from exercise participants—until immediately before the deployments.

4(a) Following the dispute arising between the United States and New Zealand over New Zealand policy on ship visits, United States policy precludes participating with New Zealand in military exercises. As a result, New Zealand has not been invited to send units to participate in Kangaroo 95. However, New Zealand has been invited to send observers to Kangaroo 95 and has accepted this invitation. Furthermore, the Australian Defence Force regularly exercises with the New Zealand Defence Force in a wide range of other settings which contribute to regional security.

(b) New Zealand's relations with the United States are a matter for the two countries themselves. Differences between the United States and New Zealand have not prevented the development of our defence relations with either party.

(c) The 1994 Defence White Paper `Defending Australia' states that our defence alliance with New Zealand is important. The ANZUS Treaty embodies formal commitments and reciprocal obligations between Australia and New Zealand and these remain in place. The importance of our defence alliance is reflected in the wide range of bilateral and multilateral activities we undertake with New Zealand.

(7) The discretion of the Council under Rule 17 is exercised as follows:
(i) the funds of the Council are used to administer and implement the Quality Improvement and Accreditation System;
(ii) no funds are paid or applied directly or indirectly by way of dividend, bonus or otherwise by way of profit to any member other than in return for services actually rendered to the Council; and

(iii) Council members are remunerated in accordance with the terms set by the Remuneration Tribunal and officers of the Council are remunerated in accordance with the terms of their employment agreements with Council which broadly follow Australian Public Service guidelines.

(8) Council approves an annual budget for each financial year. This approval provides authority for on-going running costs, (e.g. rent and salaries). A report on expenditure against the Budget is provided to Council meetings. Full Council or Executive sub-committee approval is required for other expenditure exceeding the discretionary expenditure limit of $5,000. Where possible, approval is sought prior to commitment. All payments are made by cheque, signed by the CEO and one of the three approved Council members.
